story: :root Britains youngest gran, , says people mistake me for her mum all the timeGemma Skinner, from Amersham in Buckinghamshire, was initially worried when she found out her -year-old daughter was pregnant, remembering how dficult it was to become a mum at .-year-old Gemma Skinner who has just become a grandmother, pictured with granddaughter Larosa Mae Image: The Sun News LicensingByEstel Farell-Roig:,  Oct | commentsA -year-old childminder is believed to have become Britainaposs youngest grandmother after her -year-old daughter gave birth last week. Gemma Skinner said that, when her grand-daughter was born, the nurses thought she was the babyaposs aunt.The mum-of-three said that at first she didnapost want to be called nan or granny - but that now she is loving it and couldnapost be more delighted. She said she loves being out and out with her baby grand-daughter but that, when many people see her, they believe she is the mother of week-old Larosa Maè.Ms Skinner herself had Larosaaposs mum Maizie when she was  years old and also has two more daughters: ten-year-old Gracie and Bella, who has become aunt at the age of four. Ms Skinner told the Sun : I did the school run with the baby this week and someone came over to me and askedshe was mine.“I had to explain that she’s my grand-daughter and they were quite shocked. Everyone has assumed she is Maizie’s younger sister so we have to keep explaining that she’s actually her daughter. “People mistake me for her mum all the time. “When Maizie was in hospital, the nurse who came to give her an epidural askedwe were sisters. We can laugh about it because it happens all the time. I’m used to it now.”Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror  Ms Skinner said that she was initially worried when she found out her oldest daughter was pregnant, remembering how dficult it was for her to become a mum at such young age. My first reaction was worry because it wasn’t easy for me when I found out that I was pregnant so young, she continued. “But I wouldn’t change anything for the world and I love our little family. Maizie has taken to being a mum so naturally and I’m so proud of her.” Maizie went into labour last Saturday and, after a dficult birth, the baby was born weighing lb oz at .am on Sunday.  Ms Skinner said that Maizie had to be induced and had an epidural that didnapost work work one side. The head was born for three minutes without the body, she continued, before describing the birth as very traumatic.The teenager and her boyfriend Jack Weir, , have called their baby Larosa Maè.Maizie and Jack are both now in the family home in Amersham, Buckinghamshire, so the grandmother can help out with childcare. Ms Skinner said it had been really good so far as they are a close-knit family, adding that it was lovely for the baby to have so many people around to support her. She added that her two daughters are loving being aunties and had been very sweet with their new niece. However, Ms Skinner said her own mother was not ready to be called a great-grandmother when she is in her s. Maizie said she was scared to tell her mum she was pregnant, but had received overwhelming support. “She just hugged me and told me it would be OK and supported me from then, she continued. I don’t know where I would be without her. “She’s teaching me everything I need to know and more and I’m so grateful for her. story: :root Brits could bask in festive heatwave as bookies slash odds for red hot ChristmasBrits have been betting on a hot Christmas days as a bookie said people may be considering a BBQ for their Christmas dinner this yearSwimmers of the Serpentine Swimming Club take part in the Peter Pan Cup race, which is held every Christmas Day Image: PAByEstel Farell-Roig:,  Oct | commentsBookies are expecting a toasty Christmas as Britain is forecast to have the warmest December on record. The odds for a Christmas holiday heatwave have shortened, with chances having been slashed from - to -.Instead of a White Christmas, Britons can expect a balmy holiday this December. Coralaposs John Hill told the Sun : If the latest odds are anything to go by, we could be set for a sweltering Christmas this year. We have slashed the odds on this Christmas Day being the hottest we have ever had so many people may be considering a BBQ for their Christmas dinner this year.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirrorThe bookie said Brits have been betting on a hot Christmas day.The Met Office said: Climate change has brought higher average temperatures over land and sea and this reduces the chance of a white Christmas.The definition that the Met Office uses to define a white Christmas is for one snowflake to be observed falling in the  hours of December  somewhere in the UK. The last widespread white Christmas in the UK was in , according to the forecasting service, which says Christmas is only at the beginning of the period when itaposs likely to snow as the UK is more likely to see snow between January and March. Snow days are becoming increasingly rare in the UK and only four Christmases in the last  years have recorded widespread snow weather stations.The Met Office has previously described  as a year of extremes, with the wettest February on record, the sunniest spring, a heatwave in the summer and a day in October breaking rainfall records. It said on its end of year report: This makes it clear that the general trend of warming as a consequence of c limate change is being seen, not just at a global level, but in our own national temperature records.Not only will  be one of the top five hottest on record for the UK, but also it will be one of the top ten wettest and the top ten sunniest years. story: :root Brits who catch Covid and flu together are twice as likely to die, expert warnsUK Health Security Agency chief executive Dr Jenny Harries has warned that anyone who catches both Covid and flu at the same time is twice as likely to die, compared tothey just had coronavirusDeputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries Image: PAByAine Fox:,  Oct | commentsBrits could be left facing the lethal combination of both Covid and seasonal flu this winter as vaccine immunity wanes in older people, a health chief has warned.UK Health Security Agency chief executive Dr Jenny Harries said this yearaposs flu could be multi-strain, with anyone who catches both Covid and flu at the same time being twice as likely to die, compared tothey only had coronavirus.Dr Harries also reiterated that natural immunity is lower after last yearaposs lockdown saw much lower numbers affected than an average winter. Asked how worried the public should be about flu this winter, she told Skyaposs Trevor Phillips On Sunday: We should be worried about flu each winter. I think people still donapost realise it can be a fatal disease. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Recent studies suggest that about % of us donapost actually understand that. On average, over the last five years, about , people have died with flu-related conditions. This year will be the first time flu in any real numbers and Covid will be around at the same time, she said. She added: So the risks of catching both together still remain. Andyou do that, then early evidence suggests that you are twice as likely to die from having two together, than just having Covid alone. So I think itaposs an uncertain winter ahead - thataposs not a prediction, itaposs an uncertain feature - but we do know that flu cases have been lower in the previous year so immunity and the strain types are a little more uncertain.  Explaining that this yearaposs flu could be made up of dferent strains, she said the vaccine being offered this winter season is to protect against four of those. She said: Weaposve got a pretty good array in our toolbox to try and hit whichever one becomes dominant but it could be more than one this year, and peopleaposs immunity will be lower. So I think the real trick here is to get vaccinated - in both Covid and flu - but obviously to continue to do those good hygiene behaviours that weaposve been practising all through Covid. The average flu season sees around , deaths a year.  Dr Harries insisted it is not the case that  deaths a day is seen as an acceptable death rate for Covid, and said officials are still taking it extremely seriously. She told The Andrew Marr show: We are starting to move to a situation where, perhaps Covid is not the most signicant element and many of those iniduals affected will of course have other comorbidities which will make them vulnerable to serious illness for other reasons as well. She said the extremely good vaccine uptake is now preventing very signicant amounts of hospitalisation and death, but added that this is now one of the most dficult times to predict what will come with coronavirus. She said: We have dferent levels of vaccination, we have a little bit of immunity waning in older iniduals, which is why weaposre now starting to put in a Covid booster vaccine. We have slightly dferent effectiveness in dferent vaccinations that have been provided. On a positive note, she said it appears the global dominance of the Delta iant has seen other coronavirus iants become extinct, but she added that we still need to stay alert because it is still very early days of a new virus. news uk-news empty-shelves-across-uk-amid-"Thornberry slams Governments Brexit positivity amid food shortagesByEstel Farell-Roig:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsPictures of empty shelves across the UK are emerging among reports that up to a third of lorries on the roads are completely empty.Depleted supermarket shelves have been seen across London, with supplies of milk, bread, sandwiches and fizzy drinks running low in certain stores. And a nearly empty fresh fruit and veg section was also seen in an Asda store in Cardf, where some of the freezer and fridge sections were completely empty. The news comes as millions of Brits have been unable to buy essential food in the past fortnight, with one in three already having started stockpiling for Christmas.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror This has led to calls for Britainaposs supermarkets to ditch their traditional rivalries in a bid to boost the beleaguered supply chain this Christmas and prevent almost one in three lorries on the road being completely empty. Rival retail chains have been told that they need to collaborate in the run-up to the festive season as the shortage of haulage drivers continues to threaten stock deliveries across the country. Trade magazine The Grocer reported that supermarkets have been urged to avoid a survival of the fittest Christmas this year to prevent further stresses piling onto an already creaking logistics network. The call comes as statistics from the Department for Transport show that poor utilisation of distribution capacity sees around  per cent of lorries on the road completely empty while those that contain goods are on average only  per cent full.  The Grocer said that the UKaposs ongoing driver shortage has created stf competition among supermarkets for limited haulage availability, with each retailer intent on minimising their own disruption. But as demand builds in the run-up to Christmas they have been urged to show greater collaboration to ease the burden on supply chains. Shane Brennan, chief executive of the Cold Chain Federation, told the magazine: The biggest choice every one of the major supermarkets has got this week is: are we going to have a survival of the fittest Christmas or are we going to all work together and try and get through Christmas. The problem with crisis is everyone fights to protect their own. So what you are finding is businesses fighting to protect the certainty of their own deliveries and that pushes against collaboration and co-ordination of efficiencies.  Tesco said this week that it was increasing its use of rail freight by almost per cent to help keep its shelves stocked during the driver crisis. It has also been reported that bus drivers are quitting to take up better-paid work as lorry drivers, leaving some key routes understaffed or axed entirely from the timetable, as operators point the finger at road haulage bosses for poaching their drivers in recent months. Britainaposs supply chains were brought to a standstill by the exodus of European truckers, leading to fuel shortages and empty shelves in supermarkets, as a result of the Boris Johnsonaposs governmentaposs disastrous Brexit plan.  Ministers stepped up their drive to avoid further lorry driver shortages by moving to create an additional , fast-track driver courses and almost a million letters have gone out asking HGV licence-holders who have left the industry, including bus drivers, to .At the same time, Boris Johnson has jetted off for a sunshine break in Spain, travelling to Marbella with his we Carrie and their young son Wilf on Friday after attending the Conservative Party Conference in Manchester. But Brits back home are feeling the winter chill as millions face soaring UK energy bills, food and fuel shortages, and the impact of the cut to Universal Credit. title: explorer left speechless after stumbling
story: :root Explorer left speechless after stumbling upon Knights Templar cave under a treeYouTuber Brendan James, , stumbled upon the cave in Shnal, Shropshire, and took his , subscribers on an adventure of the Caynton Caves that were rumoured to be used by the Knights Templar in the th centuryBrendan James was shocked to find these underground caves as he explored a hole under a tree Image: Brendan Explores YoutubeByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA YouTuber was left speechless when he stumbled on what he believed is a Knights Templar cave under a tree. Brendan James, , stumbled upon the cave in Shnal, Shrops., after a friend read about it online. The explorer took his , subscribers on a virtual journey as he filmed himself exploring the cave. Locals have long claimed that the Caynton Caves were used by the Knights Templar in the th century. Historic England described the cave as a grotto and believe it was built in the th century - a few hundred years after the Templar order was disbanded. Brendan said he was left feeling claustrophobic and uneasy while down in the grotto. The entrance is a small hole underneath a tree - easy for anyone to miss. He said: We went into it, and it is a small crawl space which leads to a huge sandstone cave. You wouldnapost think in a million years it would be there. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Brendan admitted he was sceptical at first. Even though the cave has been linked to the medical military group, it is likely to be a Victorian folly. Brendan said: There were some photos online, but nothing of signicance. But when I went down there it opened my eyes. It was expansive. Someone had been down there and put in the effort to make such beautul carvings.  It must have looked pristine when it was first done. The cave is covered with graffiti and Brendan also found a picture of a man in a ritual room. He also discovered a semi-collapsed wall - which sparked concerns over the safety of the structure. He said: I didnapost think I was claustrophobic, but I was thankful to get out. Brendan left the cave after about half an hour of exploring because he said he started to feel a little dazed. title: higher food prices should expected
story: :root Higher food prices should be expected, Heinz boss warns shoppersMiguel Patricio, the chief of Kraft Heinz, has said the company is raising prices around the world for a slew of products such as cupboard staples ketchup and baked beansThere are fears about empty shelves in supermarkets Image: PAByTom Davidson:,  Oct | commentsShoppers should expect to see higher food prices, according to the Kraft Heinz chief. Miguel Patricio said the firm is raising prices, where necessary, around the world of products including ketchup and baked beans. Mr Patricio said this was because of a lack of truck drivers in the UK and labour shortages and an increase in logistics costs in the US. He told the BBC consumers will need to get used to paying more for food due to the worldaposs rising population and a lack of land to grow produce. But he also said firms would have to take on the cost rises, adding: I think itaposs up to us and to the industry and to the other companies to try to minimise these price increases.  Speaking about the reason behind the increases, Mr Patricio said: Specically in the UK, with the lack of truck drivers. InUS, logistic costs also increased substantially, and thereaposs a shortage of labour in certain areas of the economy. It is also because inflation was across the board unlike in previous years, he said.Kona Haque, head of research at the agricultural commodities firm EDF Man, told the broadcaster: Whether itaposs corn, sugar, coffee, soybeans, palm oil, you name it, all of these basic food commodities have been rising.It comes amid fears over supply chain issues ahead of Christmas.  Business advisory firm BDO LLP said its research suggested that economic growth had slowed for five months in a row due to disruption.PM Boris Johnson has refused to rule out shortages at Christmas while Chancellor Rishi Sunak said distribution problems with some key goods could continue for months.Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said any shortages at supermarkets would not be the fault of No or the Government. According to the Office for National Statistics, one in six people has been unable to buy essential food items in the past fortnight.A survey by The Grocer found that a third of people had started stocking up on Christmas food and drink or were planning to by the end of October.Two-thirds of Brits said they were concerned about the shortages over the festive period. title: it doesnt feel like work
story: :root It doesn’t feel like work! - mum spices things up with surprising new careerAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Oct When it comes to decision making do you play it safe, or seek out fun and adventure  If you fancy yourself as a thrill seeker, then Zinger Popcorn is for you. To celebrate the launch of Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only - we decided to champion people who like to spice things up, including Hannah Murphy, . When she reached a career crossroads in , Hannah struck out on a new adventurous course, and almost a decade on has no regrets about her bold decision. When I was made redundant from my eight-year career as a flight attendant, flying both domestically and between the UK and Japan, I saw it as an opportunity set myself a new challenge, and have new adventures, says Hannah who lives in Southampton with her husband and three children, Angelina, , Archie,  and Adriana, five. At the time I was a single mum of one after my previous relationship ended, and the ‘sensible’ decision would have been to take a - desk job, something stable but didnapost challenge me. That’s just not me though, I have to love what I do and find joy in it every day. Instead, Hannah trained as a fitness instructor and began to incorporate a hula hoop into her training. It wasn’t just a useful exercise tool, great for toning and core strength, it was so much fun. The moment I started hula hooping, I was transported back to my childhood, it was really liberating. As word got out about Hannah’s hula hooping prowess, friends and family began to ask for lessons, followed by requests from local schools for Hannah to come in and teach children how to hula hoop.  It snowballed and before I knew it, I had so much interest in hula hooping fitness classes, I had to train other instructors to help me. I went on to create a training programme called Globe Fit and today I have teachers all around the world, from Australia to America, all teaching my programme. I love teaching hula hooping, particularly adults, because they might start off a bit self-conscious and inhibited but soon their inner child is released and they just go for it! I’ve taught people aged from teenagers to eighty-year-olds. Last year, I hosted the first ever world hula hooping championship, which will be taking place again later this year. After launching the UKaposs first hula hooping championship in , which took place in Fareham, Hampshire, Hannah decided to go global in . Not even a pandemic could stop her with the event going virtual and around twenty-five competitors, women and men of all ages and abilities, taking part from as far afield as India, America and Australia. I had a  of four judges, including John Parnell aka Hoop Guy who appeared on Britainaposs Got Talent in . Competitors submitted videos of themselves performing with their hoop, and were marked on everything from skill to tricks they could do, with the  judging the videos.  The second world championship will take place in December this year, again virtually, and I hope to have even more people taking part. It’s amazing to be a part of people experiencing something new and fun, it doesn’t feel like work! Hannah’s story is a great example of how le can get better when you try something new, soyou already love Popcorn chicken - tasty pops of  per cent chicken breast, perfect to nibble on by themselves or as a side - then itaposs time to turn up the heat. Popcorn Chicken Zinger is the same delicious chicken and moreish crunch, but KFC have pumped up the spice for those who can handle a kick. Make sure you get your hands on a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it’s only available until October .Download the app, head in store or order online. German authorities identied Christian Brueckner as a prime suspect in Maddieaposs case last year and said they had concrete evidence the missing girl was dead. Investigators are now said to be  per cent convinced the convicted sex offender is the man responsible. But the -year-old has taunted German prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters, who claims to have enough evidence to charge the rapist, saying he is bluffing.Sources close to Brueckner told The Sun Online : B and his legal team remain sure Wolters and his investigators don’t have a shred of evidence to convict him on or charge him over.  Their position has always been clear:there is evidence, show it. But the police never have. That’s why they are convinced these comments are a bluff designed to get B to crack behind bars and confess to someone. That will never happen. B believes Wolters is simply a celebrity cop looking to make headlines.” Brueckner is currently serving a seven-year sentence for raping an American tourist in Portugal in  and the prosecution team are taking time to gather as much evidence as possible before bringing allegations to court. Speaking exclusively to the Mirror, Mr Wolters said: “It is now possible that we could charge. We have that evidence now. “But it’s not just about charging him – we want to charge him with the best body of evidence possible. “When we still have questions, it would be nonsense to charge rather than wait for the answers that could strengthen our position.  “That’s why we said we’ll investigate as long as there are leads or information for us to pursue. I’m not saying that what we have is insufficient now. But he’s in prison, so we don’t have this pressure on us. We have time on our hands.” Part of the evidence being looked into by police includes an alleged confession made Brueckner made to a friend.  They are also investigating phone data that shows he was at the Ocean Club in Praia da Luz when Madeleine disappeared in . Madeleine vanished from her family’s holiday flat at the resort in Portugal days before her fourth birthday. Kate and Gerry from Rothley, Leicestershire, have said they “hang on to the hope, however small, that we will see Madeleine again”.  Last year, German cops told the McCanns last year that they had “evidence” Madeleine was no longer alive. However prosecutors now admit they have no proof she is dead. In the UK police are still treating her disappearance as a missing person case. news uk-news mum-driving-wrong-way-motorway-"HGV tries to warn reckless driver before tragic crashByJoe ThomasAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsThis is the horrying moment an HGV driver tried to alert a mum to the danger she and others were in moments before she caused a fatal car crash.The driver can be heard repeatedly sounding this horn after Ann Marie Crook, , narrowly missed the vehicle while she drove the wrong way down the slip road to the M.Moments later, she hit the Honda Jazz of Paula Kingdon, killing her.Crook had been driving for fives miles through St Helens before she hit the retired headteacher, LiverpoolEcho reports. Crook had hit speeds between mph and mph during sections of road that had a speed limit of mph.  She then crossed onto the wrong side of the road before turning onto oncoming traffic - where she passed the HGV. Chris Hopkins, prosecuting, told Liverpool Crown Court of the detailed accounts of witnesses who saw Crook in the build-up to the crash in October . Mr Hopkins said one driver told police: Suddenly he became aware of the defendantaposs car... to his disbelief she was level with him but on the other side of the crash barrier... he watched in horror as the defendant crossed the two eastbound lanes and entered the exit slip on the M.  According to another witness, earlier on in her journey: He could see her hands on the steering wheel while she was looking forward and appeared to be driving in a determined manner. One of the drivers she approached on the M recalled: The defendant appeared to pick a lane and stick with it. There was no braking. The defendant drove straight and with purpose. The court heard the vehicle in front of Paula swerved to avoid Crook, leaving the much-loved former teacher no time to react.  Mr Hopkins said Crookaposs intentions remained unclear, but added: All of the evidence indicates this was a deliberate act and the only sensible conclusion that can be drawn is that the defendant was trying to harm herself. Paula and Crook both had to be cut out of their vehicles and taken to Aintree Hospital. Crook spent time in a critical condition. The mum-of-two told police she had no recollection of the incident and suggested she had taken a wrong turn and panicked. Mr Hopkins said: The fact that that explanation is maintained by the defendant is something which has caused great distress to family members of the victim. A letter written to Judge Garrett Byrne by Crook ended with her claiming she had no explanation for her actions. Highlighting the evidence that Crook made no attempt to avoid a crash, he concluded it was not a case of taking a wrong turn and then panicking, it was a deliberate course of conduct. The judge added that,it had been Crookaposs intention to harm herself, it was a profoundly selfish one because you were prepared to injure or kill others in achieving that goal. Crook admitted one count of causing death by dangerous driving and was sentenced to four years and eight months. She was disqualied from driving for three years after her release. story: :root Mum-of-five struggling with her balance told she could have three years to liveTracy Williams went for a check-up when she started to slur her words and began struggling to stay upright, only to be told she had between three and  years left to liveTracy Williams is determined to walk down the aisle when marrying partner AndyByCharlotte Hadfield:,  Oct | commentsA mum-of-five was given devastating news by a doctor after she began to lose her sense of balance. Tracy Williams went for a check-up when she started to slur her words and began struggling to stay upright. After checks, the -year-old received the devastating news that she has Motor Neurone Disease , Liverpool Echo reported. The doctors told the Formby, Merseyside, mum that she has between three and  years to live. MND is a rare condition that affects the brain and the nervous system. Thereaposs no cure for the disease and it can signicantly shorten le expectancy, but some people live with it for many years.  Tracyaposs best friend Nikki Stewart is now on a mission to help her walk down the aisle on her wedding day before her mobility gets any worse. Tracy said: At first it was my foot, it was like it was catching on the floor and then my walking gradually got worse. I got weakness in my legs on my left side and then it started in my arm. I went to the doctors and they sent me to the neurologist for brain scans and spinal scans and things. Tracy has a history of MS in her family and initially suspected that could be the cause of her symptoms, but doctors soon ruled it out.  After undergoing tests at the Walton Centre, she was diagnosed with MND on September . Tracy said: I was heartbroken because they told me I could have three to  years to live and that was the worst shock more than anything. They told me Iaposll end up in a wheelchair and my speech will go completely and Iaposll have trouble eating. Tracy, who has five children aged , , ,  and , is determined to keep on working in her job as an office manager at a school. She is aiming to get married at the start of next year to her partner of  years, Andy Ball, , and fulfil her dream of walking down the aisle. In order to help Tracy to achieve her dream and give her and Andy a special day to remember, friend Nikki has set up a Go Fund Me page. Sheaposs my best friend - we work together, Nikki said. title: nun 85 rammed ground mugged
story: :root Nun, , rammed to the ground and mugged for her bottle of HOLY WATER by moped thugsThe -year-old victim was walking in Hull when she was floored and had her bag snatched - she had been set upon by Matthew Goodwillie and Adam FentonMatthew Goodwillie,  , was sentenced to five years and  months for his part in the robbery Image: Hull Live MENByGregory Ford:,  Oct | commentsAn elderly nun could have been killed when she was mown down and mugged for her holy water by moped thugs, Hull Crown Court heard on Friday. The elderly sister was walking in Hull on November ,  at roughly .pm when she was floored and had her bag snatched by Matthew Goodwillie, , and teenager Adam Fenton, now . The dazed victim could not remember how many people had been on the moped and only noticed that her handbag had been stolen when she was helped to her feet by a shocked bystander.A teenager riding on the back of the vehicle was identied at the time as Fenton, and officers arresting him also found a signicant amount of cannabis at his home address.Fenton then led officers to the moped driver, Goodwillie who would have avoided charges had it not been for the signicant assistance of Fenton.  For his part in the robbery and for possession with intent to supply Fenton was given a -month suspended sentence and a community order of  hours unpaid work.Goodwillie, of Hull, was identied as the leader in the abhorrent crime and received five years and  months imprisonmentfor his part in the robbery and for possession of a bladed weapon in September this year.CCTV, shown to Judge John Thackray, showed a moped passing the nun before turning around, mounting the pavement and knocking her to the ground.The contents of the handbag was mainly personal items including keys with addresses written on tags, a silver medal on a string and a bottle of holy water. All of these were ed when the bag was later found discarded. Fenton was identied as the rider of the moped seen on CCTV and upon his arrest,  bags of cannabis with a street value of around £ were found at his address alongside drugs paraphernalia. There was evidence on mobile phones also found at the address that Fenton was facing signicant pressure from people who claimed he owed them money, sent as messages on the day of the robbery.Prosecutor Ms Jessica Strange described the delays the case had faced due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.Ms Strange told the court that after pleading guilty to both the charge of robbery and possession with intent to supply, Fenton had already indicated that he was willing to assist police in locating the driver of the moped. Goodwillie had a number of previous convictions ranging from drug offences to battery and criminal damage. Defence barrister Steven Garth told the court that Goodwillie had suffered a wretched upbringing and said he had been on medication for unconfirmed schizophrenia and paranoia for a number of years. Mr Garth also confirmed that Goodwillie had experienced problems with Class A drug addiction since the age of just . Describing the robbery, Mr Garth said: It was a wicked act on his part and a terrible ordeal for the elderly victim. Judge Thackray agreed, telling Goodwillie: Your carefully chosen victim was an -year-old lady walking on her own at night, among the most vulnerable people in our society. You drove into her on a moped and rammed her to the ground, such an action could have caused serious injurynot a fatality. I have not the first trouble in identying you as the lead in this enterprise being the older man at the time of the offence and exerting considerable influence on you co-defendant. Goodwillie was sentenced to  months imprisonment for his part in the robbery and a further eight months for possession of a bladed weapon in a public place which occurred in September this year, meaning a total sentence of five years and  months. Judge Thackray recognised that without Fentonaposs help, Goodwillie would have escaped justice and that the information had been given at great personal risk with Fenton confirming he had received indirect personal threats. When passing his sentence, Judge Thackray told Fenton: You should consider yourself extremely lucky. Fenton was given a -month suspended sentence for his part in the robbery with a community order of  hours unpaid work and  days on a rehabilitation course. title: queen top royals heading climate
story: :root Queen, Charles and Prince William will attend COP Climate Change summitThe Queen, Prince Charles, Camilla, Prince William and Kate Middleton are set to attend a diplomatic reception during the the Cop climate conference in GlasgowThe Queen is set to attend a diplomatic reception during the Cop conference Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Britain will apospull out all the stopsapos at the upcoming Cop climate conference in Scotland.The Queen and senior members of the royal family will attend a series of events during the UN Climate Change conference. Glasgow is hosting the global summit and the Queen, Prince of Wales, Duchess of Cornwall, and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will carry out royal engagements from November  to . The Queen will reportedly attend a diplomatic reception, with Prince Charles, his we Camilla and son and daughter-in-law William and Kate set to join her.The Duke of Cambridge and Prince Charles are expected to deliver speeches at the conference and hold discussions with world leaders, the Dailyreports. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Bob Ward, spokesman for the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment at the London School of Economics, told the Daily : Prince Charles, and increasingly Prince William, have shown a particular interest in this area. Prince Charles is definitely recognised around the world as a deep thinker on these issues, and having a track record of having been interested in this for a long, long time. So itaposs not just the symbolism – they are people of substance on these issues.  Mr Ward added that he thought the aposstrong showingapos from the royal family was aposentirely helpfulapos as it showed the UK was serious about climate change. Gareth Redmond-King, of the UKaposs not-for-profit Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit, said the presence of the royal family at the event showed the UK was apospulling out all the diplomatic stopsapos. He added that Britain is doing everything it can to ensure countries leave the conference with the Paris Agreement goal of keeping global warming to .C within reach. Prince Charles is a long-standing environmental campaigner and has been joined in recent years by his son William, who has established the Earthshot Prize - an award recognising innovations that repair the planet.  Winners of the award, a -year project with a total prize fund of £ million, will be announced later this month. The Glasgow conference has been billed as crucial to delivering the goals of the Paris Agreement which, when it was agreed in , recognised countries needed to signicantly increase action to cut greenhouse gases. But the while the gap between meeting the temperature goals, intended to stave off the most dangerous impacts of global warming, and action has reduced since Paris, it is not set to be closed by next monthaposs summit. story: :root Schoolboy, , driving BMW on M caused horror motorway crash with lorryCristian Pompa, , pleaded guilty at Leicester Crown Court to causing serious injury by dangerous driving and was sentenced to  months detention following the crashWreckage at the scene of the crash on the M Image: Leicester LiveBySuzy Gibson:,  Oct | commentsAn underage driver ran a lorry off the road, leaving its driver stuck in the twisted wreckage. Cristian Pompa had been weaving in and out of traffic in a red BMW on the M near junction  on Thursday March  last year.The -year-old struck a car from behind, sending the vehicle and the woman inside crashing into the central reservation, reports Leicester Mercury. The smash wrote off her vehicle and caused her soft tissue injuries which required physiotherapy treatment. The boyaposs car then crashed into the front offside of a Volvo heavy goods vehicle.  David Earl, prosecuting, said: The impact wrenched the steering wheel from the lorry driveraposs hands as the steering jammed. The vehicle left the carriageway, went down a bank and tipped onto its side. The driver was trapped in his cab and had to be cut out by the fire service. The HGV was damaged beyond repair.. The prosecutor said: The lorry driveraposs injuries included three fractures to his spine, a broken right scapula and soft tissue damage to his shoulder and back. The pain was excruciating.He was off work for  weeks and has ongoing issues, including severe headaches and is still on painkillers.In a victim impact statement he said he suffers flashbacks and anxiety. Pompa, who has since turned , fled from the carnage but was arrested after his DNA was found on the blown airbag of his abandoned car. He pleaded guilty at Leicester Crown Court to causing serious injury by dangerous driving, Mr Earl said the lorry driver was also a carer for his we, who suffers from MS, and his injuries made it particularly dficult to look after her. She was traumatised by the incident and seeing him in hospital. The court heard that when arrested, Pompa, of Park Avenue, Tottenham, London - who has  non-dwelling burglaries and four thefts on his criminal record - gave a no comment interview and has never identied the driver of the red BMW who whisked him away from the crash scene.  Sentencing, Judge Robert Brown said: You were  years old and had no driving licence and should not have been behind the wheel of a car or driving down the M motorway. Your driving was appalling and whilst attempting a manoeuvre, squeezing between two vehicles, you caused a serious collision. The lorry driver was trapped and had to be rescued by others at the scene, who turned off his engine because he was unable to. There are ongoing consequences for him. Your vehicle stopped but instead of going back to see how the other drivers were you got into a car that had been following you and sped off. Fleeing the scene was utterly shameful. Iaposm told youaposre now remorseful. Priya Bakshi, mitigating, said Pompaaposs family were in court and his parents appreciated how serious the offence was. At the time Pompa was studying for his GCSEs and was hoping to do a mechanics college course having passed his exams. Miss Bakshi said Pompa was sorry and had since matured, now recognising the error of his ways. She added: Thereaposs nothing I can say to excuse what he did. He sayaposs aposIaposm guilty and I was , to say sorry is not enough andI could turn the clock back in time I would, I didnapost think of the consequences.aposI know I could have killed others and killed myself.aposPompa was sentenced to  months detention. He was banned from driving for two years and eight months. title: schoolgirls routine eye check finds
story: :root Schoolgirls routine eye check finds off-the-scale sign of stage-four brain cancerGrace Kelly, , is due to start chemotherapy and radiotherapy treatment in two weeks after she was diagnosed with brain cancer after doctors at Leicester Royal Infirmary said the swelling behind her eyes was off the scaleGrace Kelly, , was diagnosed with stage-four brain cancer last month Image: BPM MediaByAsha PatelAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA schoolgirl was diagnosed with stage-four brain cancer after going for a routine eye appointment. Grace Kelly, , was at the eye appointment with her mum Vanessa when the optician discovered swelling behind her eyes and she was referred for an MRI scan. Vanessa told LeicestershireLive: I was a little worried but I was told it was just to be safe and we had been really busy with getting ready to go back to school. On August , the day before Grace was meant to go back to school, she had an appointment at Leicester Royal Infirmary. The mum-of-three said: When the doctor had a look, he said the swelling was off-the-scale.  Do you have a story you think we should cover  Get in touch at webnews@mirrorGrace was admitted to the childrenaposs emergency department overnight. Vanessa said: I knew they had found something because they kept looking at her through the screen and talking to someone on the phone. Vanessa was then given the devastating news that Grace had a brain tumour. She said: Grace was in bits as well but I just tried to ease her fears. On September , Grace underwent a long surgery at the Queenaposs Medical Centre in Nottingham to remove the tumour.  Around  to  per cent was removed, but Vanessa was told the location of the tumour meant it could not be fully removed. One week later, following a biopsy, Vanessa and John received the news that Grace had stage-four brain cancer. She said: It was absolutely devastating. Itaposs all still fresh for our family. Grace is due to start chemotherapy and radiotherapy treatment in two weeks - the severity of the tumour means it is harder to treat and can spread quickly. Vanessa and John have been constantly researching Graceaposs condition. Grace has been able to go to school on a part-time basis but with her hospital visits, Vanessa has had to take time off work. Vanessa said: She was looking forward to getting the bus to school with her friends and she was just starting to get more independence with her friends. Family friend Hannah Huggins has stepped in to raise money for future treatments that Grace might need. Hannah will be taking part in a sponsored skye on October  to raise funds for the family. She has also planned a coffee afternoon on October  with a number of family-friendly activities at Smeeton Westerby Village Hall, near Kibworth. Families will be invited to take part in a raffle, childrenaposs game and enjoy sweet streets and refreshments. All of the money raised at the event will go to the Kelly family. You can help the family by donating to the fundraiser here. news uk-news so-many-were-dying-began-"Mirror Head Strong:  call centre worker shares mental health storyByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Oct | commentsA siren goes off in our control room when there’s a category  call, one where there’s an immediate threat to le. That alarm will go offsomeone’s not breathing. And during the Covid pandemic it felt like it was going off constantly. Being an ambulance dispatcher is already a stressful job, when every day you see and hear things that most people don’t see in their letimes. But during Covid, especially during the second and third waves, the call volume went through the roof. It was the worst thing I’ve seen in my le. Every call seemed to be either someone dying of Covid, or suffering with their mental health because of the pandemic. It was like that on repeat, and that takes its toll on you.Have you struggled with your mental health in lockdown  Email webnews@mirror to tell your story There were so many people who were dying, in their homes, at the supermarket. I’d sometimes spend two to four hours talking to a suicidal caller. A couple of people have even taken their own le while on the phone. I was shocked at how many calls I was taking from elderly people who were struggling. Normally they are the strong ones, the ones who always impressed me by just battling on, yet now they were having real problems with their mental health because they’d spent so much time on their own. I would think, ‘God, you remind me of my Nan, or my Grandad’. It was a really scary time.  When someone stops breathing we always send three resources - a manager, a paramedic and an ambulance - so there are enough people to save their le. But resources were started to get really stretched. I remember on one sht when I was dispatching during the second lockdown when so many people weren’t breathing that for the first time in my career I didn’t know what to do. It felt like all of our crews were already busy with other patients.The Daily Mirror is launching our new campaign HeadStrong: Better Mental Health For All. We’re calling for:Early Access Mental Health Hubs for under s to be rolled out across the country, with at least one for each trust. Waiting times to be cut so people actually start treatment with a professional within four weeks The Govt to fill in the gaps in care - an end of red tape which means many don’t fit the set criteria to get help plus , more mental health staffCompulsory Mental Health education lessons in schools, plus paid counsellors in schools and care homesWant to help  Write to your MP and ask them to support the current Early Day Motion  to debate mental health and the pandemic in parliament. In  my best friend, also an emergency dispatcher, took his own le. I took it badly, and my employers paid for therapy, which carried on into the pandemic and which helped me cope during the first wave. But those sessions were now over. When you’re spending so much time dealing with suicides and deaths, you become negative. I began to feel so low and unable to cope, like I was in a bottomless pit I couldn’t get out of. I started having anxiety attacks before going to work, and was vomiting before and after every sht. I worried constantlyI would have enough ambulances and crews, and about my staff too, who were terried. I felt like the worst person when I had to send them to a Covid patient as we weren’t quite sure what we were sending them to. Access the Mirror’s mental health resource hubIt got so bad that every time the emergency alarm went off I would jump, the noise was causing me so much anxiety. I was even hearing it in my head when I went home. After every sht I would call my friend and just start crying, even though I didn’t know exactly why I was crying. I started taking antidepressants but although they helped me sleep they just made me feel numb. I asked for more therapy sessions but I was declined because there were so many other staff on the waiting list for mental health support. I’m grateful for the therapy I did get though, the weekly phone calls with a psychologist made me a stronger person and I don’t know where I’d be without them.  It’s scary how many of my colleagues are dealing with mental health issues. They are some of the strongest people I’ve ever met, and many are messaging me to tell me they are struggling too. Mental health support in the emergency services has to be the best of the best, becauseyou can’t look after yourself how can you look after others  At the moment blue light staff generally receive six to  one-hour sessions of therapy, but in some cases that isn’t enough. I firmly believe we need more funding for mental health support at every level, but especially in the emergency services where we deal with le and death situations every day.How to get help: If you are struggling or you are worried about a loved one, contact Samaritans on . title: toddler 36th operation rare condition
story: :root Toddler about to have her th operation as rare condition stops her swallowingElla Davies, from Carmarthenshire, Wales, suffers from a rare condition which stops her from swallowing and means she requires surgery to keep her oesophagus openElla Davies has undergone  operations within two years Image: Leah EvansByRobert HarriesMatthew DreschReporter:,  Oct | commentsA toddler is ing to the operating theatre for her th operation in two years.Ella Davies has to travel to hospital every three weeks for a procedure that allows her to eat and drink, WalesOnline reports.She suffers from a rare condition which stops her from swallowing and means she requires surgery to keep her oesophagus open. The youngster, who celebrated her second birthday this week, has spent eight weeks in three dferent intensive care units so far this year. She will now have to undergo her th operation in just a matter of days. When Ella, from Cross Hands in Carmarthenshire, Wales, was born her oesophagus was not formed correctly. Even before her birth in October,  she had also been diagnosed with Dextracardia, which means her heart was on the right hand side of her chest.  Her parents, Leah Evans and Arwel Davies, knew early on that Ella would have to be a fighter. Leah said: “From month six of the pregnancy I had to live in a hospital in Bristol in case she was born early, andshe was I needed to be in the best place for her. Ella even had to be resuscitated at birth due to being born with a myriad of health conditions, including Scimitar Heart Syndrome, Right Lung Pulmonary Hypoplasia, and Tracheo-Oesophagael Fistula, the latter of which means she can’t swallow. “On day three she had quite a big operation, which took six hours, to try to fix her oesophagus, which was split,” said Leah. On top of that, part of her oesophagus was connected to her airways and she spent nine weeks in intensive care. Since that first operation she has had  further operations which basically keep her oesophagus open.” Despite being most parents’ worst nightmare, driving Ella to the hospital in Bristol has become a part of le for Leah and Arwel. However, things took an even more frightening turn during the summer. At first she only had a bit of a cough, but the situation soon involved a le-saving operation, this time in London. “Ella woke up with a cough and doctors thought she had bronchiolitis - but she just wasn’t breathing well and was being sick, Leah said.  “She ended up spending  days in the high dependency unit in Glangwili Hospital in Carmarthen, but on day  she deteriorated and was taken to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf, before being taken to see her usual specialist in Bristol. A hole had been discovered in her airway and she was placed on advanced le support after pneumonia spread to her lungs, which had both collapsed, and she had to be sedated and ventilated for two weeks. “The milk she had been drinking had been seeping into her lungs, which caused a huge chest infection and organ failure. She had a major operation at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London on July , which saved her le.” Since ing from London, Ella is able to breathe and feed and go about her day as best as she can. However, the puree and milk she depends on for nutrition begins to get stuck in her oesophagus after around three weeks, hence the need for the regular trips across the Severn Bridge for yet more operations. “It’s obviously quite stressful because we have to keep an eye on her all the time, to make sure she’s breathing and feeding OK,” said Leah. “The plan was for her to have a big operation towards the end of this year that would make things easier and take away the need for the other operations every three weeks, but what she went through in July has put a halt to that plan, at least for now. “Nothing is certain. Her surgeon said it is the most severe case he has seen in years. The hope is that as she gets bigger her oesophagus will get bigger, but we don’t know what the future holds really. Our main worry is thatshe continues to have more and more operations it might cause her to have dficulties with her breathing, like she had in July.” This year alone, Ella has spent eight weeks in three dferent intensive care units, as well as the trips back and forth to Bristol for operations that have now become routine. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter During their ious trips to dferent hospitals, Leah and Arwel have been provided with accommodation close by thanks to three charity houses - Ronald McDonald House in Cardf, Cots for Tots in Bristol, and The Sick Children’s Trust in London. All have made it possible for Ella to have her parents nearby as she has undergone ious operations and stayed in hospitals, sometimes for weeks on end. To say thank you to those charity houses, the couple’s colleagues are trying to raise money so that other families can receive similar support. More than £, has already been raised through a Go Fund Me page, and fundraisers will be completing a -mile bike ride on October  - the distance from Ella’s home in west Wales to Great Ormond Street, where her le was saved in July.All the money raised will be split between the three charities, who have all made desperate times just a little bit easier for Leah and Arwel over the past two years. If you wish to donate, you can do so here. She and partner Arwel previously raised money for the Wales Air Ambulance, which airlted Ella from Bristol to Swansea in . “On one occasion the charity house was full and I had to pay £ for a night in Bristol as it was the only room I could find at the last minute,” revealed Leah. “But, thankfully, that hotel stay was a one-off: we’d be bankrupt by nowwe had to pay for hotels all the time!” Ella herself is oblivious to the whirlwind going on around her, and even smiles as she enters the ward every three weeks ready for yet another operation. “She goes into the hospital smiling because she knows all the nurses!” said Leah. “That’s lovely of course but also sad because it reminds us how often she’s been there. The last time we went, in September, I was holding her hand as they gave her the general anaesthetic and she just looked up at me and said ‘ta-ta’ as she closed her eyes. She knew she was being put to sleep again. “I had a bit of an emotional moment then I must admit.” Comment MORE ON Babies" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uk records lowest ever butterfly
story: :root UK records lowest ever butterfly numbers as climate crisis threatens insectsButterfly Conservation, which counted butterflies and moths between July  and August , said the results marked the lowest numbers since the Big Butterfly Count started years ago and called for urgent actionThe UK has recorded its lowest ever number of butterflies Image: Geoffrey Swaine REX ShutterstockByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  Oct | commentsWhere have all the ­butterflies gone  This summer you may have noticed a lack of common blues or peacock butterflies in your garden or local park. In the latest warning for nature, the UK has recorded its lowest ever number in an annual survey of the insects.And the future looks even bleaker after ­scientists warned the decline could accelerate due to more extreme weather linked to climate change.Butterfly Conservation, which counted butterflies and moths between July  and August , said the results marked the lowest numbers since the Big Butterfly Count started years ago and called for urgent action. As well as being a vital part of the food chain, butterflies are signicant indicators of the health of the environment. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The number of peacock butterflies fell by % compared with last year, while the common blue declined by %, speckled wood by % and small tortoiseshell by %. On average, nine butterflies or moths were spotted per -minute count by , volunteers, down from  in , and  in . A handful of species, including marbled white and ringlet, rose from low levels during last year’s count. Butterfly Conservation said heavy downpours in May, when England had the highest rainfall for that month since , hampered breeding and feeding.  “Butterflies don’t like rain at all, they’re coldblooded. Effectively they’re solar-powered,” the charity said. “With more climate ­change-related extreme weather likely, the impact on some of the UK’s most loved insects could be devastating.” The State of the UK’s Butterflies report, a scientic survey last published in , found three quarters of Britain’s ­butterflies had declined since . The large blue is an exception, with numbers growing since it was reintroduced in  via caterpillars from Sweden. Julie Williams, the charity’s chief ­executive, said: “The facts are clear. Nature is in crisis and we need urgent action, not just to prevent further species losses but to rebuild bioersity.” Comment MORE ON Climate changeInsectsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: while covid itself doesnt discriminate
story: :root Shameful Tory cuts of mental health services have let down a generationOn World Mental Health Day, Dr Rosena Allin-Khan shares what shes seen firsthand on the NHS frontline and what she thinks needs to changeDr Rosena Allin-Khan has kept up regular shts as an NHS hospital doctor since being elected MP Image: Steve BainbridgeopinionByDr Rosena Allin-Khan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Ever since I was elected as an MP, Iaposve kept up regular shts as an NHS hospital doctor. Itaposs so important to give something back infor the trust placed in me. But no training could have prepared me for what I experienced during the Covid pandemic. Whether I was treating patients, or serving my constituents in Parliament, my view of le changed fundamentally.We all know the awful toll of statistics: , dead, , hospitalised, over two million estimated to be suffering from the devastating effects of long Covid. But less is known about a serious side-effect of the crisis - its impact on peopleaposs mental health. Inevitably, things have been made worse because of a decade of neglect from the Conservative Government. Waiting lists are soaring, hospital admissions for mental illnesses are up and patients continue to be sent miles away from home for treatment. Shamefully, the Tories have cut a quarter of all mental health beds in England since . Labour would begin to put things right: weaposd guarantee mental health treatment within a month for all who need it, setting a new NHS target, and ensuring that patients start receiving appropriate treatment – not simply an initial assessment of needs – within a month of being referred. Labour would recruit , new staff so that one million more people could access treatment every year by the end of our first term in office and ensure that mental health gets its fair share every time new funding is provided to the NHS.Tory ministers are not taking the action we need to end the mental health crisis. Only Labour will enact the real change needed to improve millions of lives. It breaks my heart, as a frontline medic, to have to tell patients that the services they rely on just are not there anymore, like the addiction support services so many desperately need. With liaison nurses working flat out, emergency departments around the country - often badly short-staffed - have to send home those struggling with addiction and seeking help.This World Mental Health Day the theme is ‘Mental Health in an Unequal World’ – very fitting after the pandemic has laid bare the inequalities we all face, including here in the UK. While the virus itself doesnapost discriminate, it hasnapost hit all of our communities equally. The inequalities are vast and stark. Many of the frontline staff who died from Covid- were Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic.As Doreen Lawrence ’s review showed, the causes of Covid’s disproportionate impact on these communities were systemic. I was told of many incidents, across multiple hospitals, which showed the impact of these structural inequalities on inidual Black hospital housekeeping staff, who were being sent to clean rooms, without protective masks and gowns, after patients had died from Covid.As I saw first-hand in intensive care, row after row of patients were from our Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities. Some of them had, in turn, been caring for our loved ones, stacking our supermarket shelves and keeping our public transport moving.It was the health inequalities that are all too prevalent in our society that permitted the virus to ravage our communities - to the eternal shame of Tory ministers. The knock-on impact on mental health is devastating and is all too visible on the frontline including, for instance, the rising numbers of eating disorders in young Asian women.Extra s must be taken to ensure mental health treatments are tailored for specic communities. When I was training in AE, for example, I learned that in some languages, there isn’t even a word for depression – instead terms such as ‘all-over body pain’ are used to describe a range of mental illnesses. Our communities are being failed - but the Tories donapost care. Only Labour can ensure that proper action is taken before itaposs too late.The Daily Mirror is launching our new campaign HeadStrong: Better Mental Health For All. We’re calling for:Early Access Mental Health Hubs for under s to be rolled out across the country, with at least one for each trust. Waiting times to be cut so people actually start treatment with a professional within four weeks The Govt to fill in the gaps in care - an end of red tape which means many don’t fit the set criteria to get help plus , more mental health staffCompulsory Mental Health education lessons in schools, plus paid counsellors in schools and care homesWant to help  Write to your MP and ask them to support the current Early Day Motion  to debate mental health and the pandemic in parliament. The Government is also letting down a generation of young people. Even before the pandemic, children were being denied desperately needed treatment – in  , % were turned away from mental health services despite a referral from a professional. During the pandemic, this figure has soared to % of our children. They are lost in the system - the hidden victims of the pandemic and a decade of Tory cuts. Their futures are uncertain and the effect on them and their families is appalling. In AE, it often feels that the age of those coming in self-harming or with eating disorders is getting younger and younger. When I first started  years ago, it was not uncommon to see teens, but now my colleagues and I are having to treat far too many young children, often pre-teen, with some as young as . Trust in the system has been entirely degraded over time. How I hate having to be the doctor who tells another teenager that Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services simply can’t come and see them, again.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror  All our children deserve proper mental health services so their illnesses can be caught, and treated, as early as possible. That’s why the next Labour Government is committed to providing specialist mental health support in every school, to support pupils and resolve problems before they escalate. Labour would put a full-time mental health professional in every secondary school and a part-time professional in every primary school. For all the children who would feel safer accessing mental health support outside of school, Labour is committed to having an open-access mental health hub for children and young people in every community, providing early intervention and drop-in services.  Throughout the pandemic, our health and care staff have been the glue that have held our country together. The impact that Covid has placed on them, coming after years of erosion of our public services, is taking its toll. Colleagues from across the country are telling me they are burned out, exhausted beyond measure and concerned that the pressure on services means they can’t always give their patients the very best of themselves. Labour announced our Care for Carers package last June, to ensure that all three million health and care staff could get the tailored support they need as a result of the extra pressures they face because of this virus. None of us NHS and care professionals were trained to face this much death. It’s been hugely, but predictably, disappointing then that the Government has persistently ignored our concerns and those of frontline staff across the country – no amount of clapping, however well-intentioned, will ease the burden - only properly tailored support will. Ministers must stop ignoring staff. Otherwise, they shouldn’t be surprised when more and more leave the professions they love so much. I’m proud to support the Mirror’s HeadStrong campaign – it seeks to make such huge progress in reducing the stigma around mental illness, encouraging more people to seek help. We now need a government which will ensure that proper support and treatment is available when people need it the most. This Conservative Government is failing the mental health needs of our country – only Labour has a truly transformative package to tackle one of the most urgent issues of our time. title: young people spend long staring
story: :root Young people spend so long staring at screens half may need glasses in  yearsPhone devices and computer screens are to blame for the rising risk of short-sightedness among children and young adults, say scientists, and fear by  half the population could be short-sightedPhone devices and computer screens are to blame Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJoe Morgan:,  Oct | commentsYoung people spending hours staring at screens means half the world may need glasses within  years. Phone devices and computer screens are to blame for the rising risk of short-sightedness among children and young adults, say scientists. Researchers have found high levels of looking at a phone or tablet is linked with around a  per cent higher risk of short-sightedness, also known as myopia. But when it is combined with excessive computer use, that risk rose to around  per cent. Researchers fear that this could mean that by , half the world or five billion people could be short-sighted. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The authors examined more than , studies investigating smart device exposure and myopia in children and young adults aged between three months old and  years old. In , the World Health Organisation recommended children under two should not have any screen time and children aged two to five should have no more than one hour a day of sedentary screen time. But in the same year, a CensusWide survey of , British families found children were spending an average of  hours a week staring at screens. Numerous studies have also suggested that number has vastly increased during the Covid- pandemic. Professor Bourne, Professor of Ophthalmology in the Vision and Eye Research Institute at Anglia Ruskin University, said: Around half the global population is expected to have myopia by , so it is a health concern that is escalating quickly. Our study is the most comprehensive yet on this issue and shows a potential link between screen time and myopia in young people. This research comes at a time when our children have been spending more time than ever looking at screens for long periods, due to school closures, and it is clear that urgent research is needed to further understand how exposure to digital devices can affect our eyes and vision.We also know that people underestimate their own screen time, so future studies should use objective measures to capture this information. The study was published in The Lancet Digital Health. title: insurers 325 years claims elephant
story: :root Insurer’s  years of claims, from elephant breaking into car to a leapfrog injuryAviva has trawled through its archives to unearth a “treasure trove” of insurance claims ahead of its th anniversary next monthOne of the claims included an elephant breaking into a car Image: Hulton ArchiveByJonathan ColesReporter:,  Oct | commentsA top insurance firm has revealed some of the quirkiest claims from its centuries-old history - including a leapfrogging vicar and a hungry elephant. Aviva has trawled through its archives to unearth a “treasure trove” of claims ahead of its th anniversary next month. The company’s roots can be traced back to the Hand-in-Hand Fire and Le Insurance Company, founded in . Its first policy was taken out on January ,  and the first claim was paid on May  of that year, when houses in St Stephen’s Alley, Westminster, were “damnyed by fire”. Although the company was then an insurer against fire, the organisation evolved as people’s needs changed, to cover homes, personal possessions, motoring, travel, health and personal injuries, pensions and investments.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter And researchers found that injury claims appeared throughout the archives - particularly when health and safety rules were less comprehensive than they are today. In , a surgeon suffered a “poisoned hand” when unpacking a box of drugs. Another man injured his arm when his finger was caught in a woman’s corset in , as he was trying to save her from drowning. And, in the same year, £ was awarded to someone who lost a toenail while getting into bed. Aviva said that while many of its older claims are light on detail, they also include a vicar who was awarded £ after falling while playing leap-frog in . In another case, a London hotel keeper was awarded £ and  shillings in  after being hit in the eye with a cork after opening a bottle of champagne. Looking at th century claims, a window  of a Morris Minor van was broken in  after a circus passed by.  One of its elephants put its trunk through the window, discovered the driver’s lunch and ate it, finishing it off with a loaf of bread. Unfortunately, the elephant was a tight fit in the van. In another case, in , a policyholder and his family went away for a holiday, and for safety, his we placed her jewels in the stove. On their , the stove was lit by the husband - with disastrous results for the jewellery. Anna Stone, Aviva archivist said: “It’s been a joy to have another opportunity to look at some of our oldest and quirkiest claims. “Some of them never fail to raise a smile but, in each case, we’ve been there to help customers as they’ve faced the unexpected.  “Aviva’s origins can be traced back  years so, as we celebrate this landmark, I’ve enjoyed reminding myself of the likes of a driving red setter and a hungry elephant. “Although it has to be said, we’re still adding to our log of unusual claims even today.” Aviva has also been an insurer to some famous customers, including Sir Walter Scott, Agatha Christie, Percy Bysshe Shelley, former prime minister David Lloyd George, and royals Queen Victoria and George V. The company celebrates its th anniversary on November . Type  nuclear submarines that have the ability to hit the US.The subs are said to be able to carry Chinaaposs JL- aposBig Waveapos missiles, which have a range of , miles and could devastate US title: designer left covered head toe
story: :root Designer left covered head-to-toe in bandages after fireplace explosionOlivier Rousteing, creative director of fashion house Balmain, shared his ordeal for the first time since suffering severe burns at his home last yearOlivier Rousteing attends the Balmain Homme Menswear Fall Winter - show Image: Getty ImagesByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA celebrated fashion designer who is close to the Kardashians has revealed he was left with severe burns after a fireplace exploded at his home. Olivier Rousteing, creative director of fashion house Balmain, shared a photo of his entire body and head covered in bandages as well as burn marks on his face.The French designer posted the picture on his Instagram account on Saturday, a year exactly after the incident.He said he finally felt ready to share his experience. “I’ve been hiding this for too long and it’s time for you to know,” he wrote. “Exactly a year ago, the fireplace inside my house exploded.”  He said he woke the next day at Parisaposs Hôpital Saint Louis, and has since been recovering from his wounds. He added that he had tried to hide the story of his injuries “from as many people as possible” and had tried to keep the secret with his teams and friends “for too long”. “To be honest I am not really sure why I was so ashamed, maybe this obsession with perfection that fashion is known for and my own insecurities…,” he continued.  Instead, he tried to hide his scars “with face masks, turtlenecks, long sleeves and even multiple rings” in photoshoots and interviews. A year on, Mr Rousteing described himself as “healed, happy and healthy” and thanked the medical staff who had treated him despite dealing with an incredible number of Covid cases at that same time”. Referring to the Balmain Spring Summer  show, he said it was about the celebration of healing over pain and I thank all the models the productions my team the models my Balmain family, my friends that came and supported not only my  years of Balmain but my rebirth.”  He concluded the post by writing: “There is always the sun after the storm.”The designer also shared photos of himself “hiding” in long sleeved clothing and face masks during the summer on his Instagram stories, calling it the “most dficult summer of my le”. At the age of , Mr Rousteing became the youngest and only Black creative director in the history of Balmain. The Bordeaux-born designer marked a decade at the Paris-based fashion house at this yearaposs Fashion Week with a retrospective of his Balmain designs and his spring  collections for women and men. news world-news five-children-orphaned-parents-among-"Orenburg: Russian authorities seize boxes of bootleg vodkaByLorraine King:,  Oct | commentsFive young children have been orphaned after their parents were among  people who died from drinking bootleg vodka. Murat Berekeshov, , and his we Aislu, , drank the fake alcohol to celebrate assembling new furniture for their family home in Orsk, Russia. Aislu fell ill and had to be rushed to hospital after taking a few sips of the toxic hooch which prompted Murat to call his sister and ask her to look after their children. But soon afterwards Murat, a security worker, also became ill and had to be rushed to hospital. The couple died in hospital five hours apart. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Other victims include pensioner Aleksandr Sirotinin, , and Dmitry Karelin, , and Zhan Nurmakanov, , both unemployed, who all died. The death toll from the counterfeit alcohol containing highly toxic methanol currently stands at  with another -plus victims in hospital including -year-old Dmitry Granchenko. There are also victims who are sick at home. Methanol is a toxic alcohol used industrially as a solvent, pesticide, or fuel source.  A local official said the methanol concentrations in the body was “- times higher than a lethal dose. A seller of the deadly drink Ildar Suyunshalinov said: “I bought the alcohol at the Orsk wholesale base. “I did not know it was lethal.” Police said it is a “miracle” that more of the bootleg booze was not sold causing additional deaths.  The ages of the dead were from  to , said reports. Some of the dead were found in vehicles trying to reach hospitals after buying the alcohol which had labels suggesting it was a Siberian-label vodka. A major criminal investigation is underway with two men aged  and , and a woman, , arrested. Later it was reported that two further men and one woman were held in connection with the poisoning.  More than , bottles have been confiscated, although the fake alcohol is visibly indistinguishable from normal alcohol. “More than , empty plastic bottles and equipment for the production, storage, bottling and subsequent packaging of alcohol-containing products in large volumes were seized,” said a law enforcement report.  The fatalities come less than a year after seven people in Russiaaposs Far East republic of Yakutia died in November after consuming diluted hand sanitiser. The consumption of spirits and household products containing alcohol is fairly common in Russiaaposs poorer regions and is blamed for a large number of alcohol-related deaths. The regionaposs governor Denis Pasler issued an urgent appeal to the local population to refrain from buying alcohol.
