title: letters-leave-voters-owe-rest-us-apology
story: On a more personal level, Ive just heard from a friend in Germany that he received a book I sent him. Wersquove been exchanging the occasional gt for more than  years now. Not only did the book take twice as long to reach him as it did before Brexit, but he had to collect it from the sorting office and pay euro customs charges. The value of the item on the customs declaration form was pound. If this is how Brexit can affect a private inidual, what is it like for those who are trying to export to EU countries All this could have been avoided by the UK leaving the EU but remaining in the single market and customs union. It has now become equally obvious that lack of freedom of movement of people has landed the UK with its huge labour shortage. Expect more special work visas to be issued as the truth begins to bite in many sectors of the economy.Itrsquos the denials which I find bizarre. Anyone with half a brain can see that Brexit has been bad news for the UK. Wersquove treated our European allies like dirt, created major dficulties for UK export businesses, damaged the lives of UK citizens settled in EU countries , got into yet another mess with Northern Ireland, and shown Britain to be untrustworthy when it comes to signed agreements.Irsquom still waiting for some honest reservations to be uttered by those who voted Leave, evenpride prevents them from offering the actual apology that we Remainers deserve.Dave Stewart, Glasgow.HAVE FAITH IN FELLOW SCOTSROBERT IG Scottasks ldquowhat benefits would Scotland derive from the SNPrsquos dream of independence . It is a simple question requiring a voluminous answer and to simply the answer, I say look at similar-sized countries of Europe and where. Naturally SNP supporters wish to see Scotland become independent, but there are many voters from other parties who also support independence and will vote accordingly when the time comes.The Little Englander view of the UK is somewhat inward-looking as it is not only the UK which is multi-cultural but the wider world. Look beyond UK borders and blue passports and have faith in your fellow Scots to make a go of things.Independence would change everything and give the people some hope from the real mess created under successive Westminster governments over a long period of time. More of the same is our future right now and how much better to ldquotake back control and run ourselves with a government chosen from parties standing only in Scotland whether that be SNP, Conservative, Labour or from other newly-formed parties. In Scotlandrsquos past history lies our future.Alan M Morris, Blanefield.BORDERS THAT REALLY HURTROBERT IG Scott would like the Scotland England border to be consigned to the history books with the UK retained in its present form for ever more. He fails to share his attitude to Brexit through which the voters south of that border in his beloved UK have imposed a border at the English Channel and another across the island of Ireland, casting us adrt from our fellow Europeans and endangering both the hard-won peace settlement in Ireland and the fellowship among the major European nations which the EU had brought about.The EU was as precious to me and millions of others as the UK is to Mr Scott.Willie Maclean, Milngavie.BENEFITS OF INDEPENDENCEROBERT IG Scott asks what benefits Scotland would derive from restoring its independence. Letrsquos start with the most obvious. It would give us a government that is directly accountable to the people of Scotland, meaning we would no longer suffer rule by a government we didnrsquot vote for, and havenrsquot, since .Second, it would give us control over our economy. We would be able to set our own interest rates and make tax, spending and investment decisions for the benefit of Scotland, not England. We could keep our money and not have to send half to Westminster. We could eliminate poverty, raise the miserly state pension, invest in health, education, social care and a greener economy, creating millions of good well-paid jobs.Third, it would give us control over our considerable natural resources ndash oil, renewables, forestry, fishing, and land. Had we managed our oil ourselves, we could have created a sovereign wealth fund, as Norway did, to secure the future of generations of Scots. We canrsquot allow Westminster to steal our renewables and water as climate change accelerates.Fourth, independence means we could make our own foreign policy, and not be ripped from the worldrsquos largest free trading bloc against our will. We could manage our defence at a much lower cost and remove weapons of mass destruction from our soil. We could sign international agreements like the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child without being slapped down for exceeding our authority.The benefits of reclaiming our sovereignty are overwhelming. Lets get on with it.Leah Gunn Barrett, Edinburgh.NO CLEAR INDY MANDATEFRASER Grantrefers to the May Scottish Parliament election results and how the fact that the SNP won  seats as against only  by the other parties and says that provides a clear mandate for Indyref.While these statistics are accurate, further examination shows that the  seats were won with . per cent of the total votes cast in the constituency vote. The SNP won .% of the total votes cast in the regional vote and of the combined votes cast in both elements of the election the SNP won .% of the total. While this shows strong support for the SNP it clearly does not demonstrate a clear mandate for Indyref.Simply repeating the claim "we have a clear cast-iron mandate for Indyref" does not make it become true.James Hamilton, Glasgow.PUT SEPARATION ON BALLOTSWHILE I sympathise with Jill Stephensons frustration with the distortion caused by leading referendum questionsI fear that her well-meaning intention to rebalance a second referendum question for it to say "lsquoShould Scotland remain in the UK  Yes or No" would have unforeseen repercussions.Indyref is often spoken about as a simple repeat of Indyref and most ordinary people who dont follow the exact minutiae of politics would assume the same and look at it in the context of their last vote on the same subject. For No to become Yes and Yes to become No would only confuse people. I can well imagine tens of thousands of people thinking that they were reaffirming support for the same thing as they did last time ndash or registering that theyve changed their mind from last time ndash only to realise afterwards that they were actually voting for the exact opposite of what they wanted.I agree with Ms Stephenson that the pro-nationalist phrasing of the  vote was unfair, but we have to play the hand weve been dealt ndash to change could actually skew results even further. If there is to be a second referendum, andit is to have a "Yes No" question, it will have to be the same one as last time.Ideally though the least ambiguous answers should be statements of what would actually happen. Accepting that "Remain Leave" has been contaminated by the Brexit debate and cannot be used, "Union Separation"would be more direct and less judgemental than "Yes No".Robert Frazer, Dundee.* FOLLOWING on from the contribution from Peter A RussellI propose the referendum ballot paper should consist of two boxes: one marked ldquoIndependence and the other marked ldquoDependence.The latter seems to be a good description of the state most supporters of the status quo consider Scotland to be in.This should overcome the ldquoYes bias issue to everyonersquos satisfaction.Cameron Crawford, Rothesay.VERILY A DING-DONGI ALWAYS enjoy the political ding-dong on your Letters Pages: the Tories criticising everything about Scotland, loathing the SNP, and now those dreadful Greens too, and the independence supporters hitting back with their forceful responses.The saddest letters are from Labour supporters. Normally older and male, these contributors seem to live in the past and cant accept that Labour are now irrelevant to younger Scots. As for the LibDems, who Keep up the good work.Douglas Morrison, Drymen.

title: epic-1930s-cycle-tour-three-intrepid-sisters-revived
story: It was  and armed with their haversacks, meagre supplies and ndash just as well, as it turned out - puncture repair kits, -year-old Mary Harvie and her two older sisters set off on an epic  miles cycling holiday that would take in glorious scenery, lead to a string of joyful encounters and countless simple but delightful pleasures.The sistersrsquo remarkable two-week journey, faithfully recorded by the teenage Mary in her holiday diary, saw them gleefully conquer gruelling uphill tracks on bikes which came with none of todayrsquos comfy saddles and slick gears, then savouring the glorious freewheel back downhill whenever they could.Apparently undaunted by the huge distances that set themselves to cover during their two-week break - and quite unlike todayrsquos road trippers seeking a good supply of restaurants, coffee stops and comfy beds - they grabbed sustenance on the way thanks to the kindness of locals, cooled off in babbling burns and bedded down in one of Scotlandrsquos newly established youth hostels.Maryrsquos charming diary of the road trip, which recorded the ups and downs of their route, the stunning views and the acts of kindness that kept them going, was found after her death by her son.He then handed it to Hostelling Scotland as an enthralling memento of days gone by.Now the sistersrsquo impressive cycling holiday is to be partly recreated by a modern team of women cyclists, to mark Hostelling Scotlandrsquos th anniversary and VisitScotlandrsquos forthcoming Year of Storytelling.The trio from The Adventure Syndicate ndash a collective of female cyclists who take on mammoth challenges and work to inspire girls to cycle ndash will set off on Thursday for a week covering around half of the route taken by Mary and sisters Jean and Ella.Unlike Maryrsquos handwritten diaries, they will upload images and reflections of their journey to social media sites.Their bikes will also be in a dferent league from the Harvie sistersrsquo ndash they plan to tackle a route from Glasgow to Crianlarich and Glencoe, then to Portree, Torridon, Gairloch before finishing at Aviemore, on modern drop handlebar cycles with chunky wheels.One signicantly dferent factor will be the roads: while the sisters rarely encountered traffic, they did have to content with bumpy roads and loose gravel which caused more than one uncomfortable tumble and several punctures.However, like the sisters, cyclists Lee Craigie, Alice Lemkes, and PhilBattye from The Adventure Syndicate will stay where they can in youth hostels and be largely self-sufficient.Maryrsquos diary, recently published in Hostelling Scotlandrsquos membersrsquo handbook, suggests that a route which even by modern standards would be a daunting journey, posed few problems for the plucky trio.Having set off from Glasgowrsquos Anniesland Cross at am one July morning, they pointed their cycles north for Ardlui where they sunbathed and explored Glen Falloch before making their way to Crianlarich.Despite having already covered around  miles, they spent the following day hiking up Ben More.Perhaps as a sign of the times, the sisters do not appear to have any lsquostranger dangerrsquo fears while lorry drivers and other road users seem keen to help them on their way.Their journey from Crianlarich to Ballinchulish was eased thanks to a friendly lorry driver.ldquoLorry passed us and he waved, wrote Mary of the journey from Crianlarich to Ballinchulish.ldquoWhen we turned the corner, he was stopped. He offered us a lt to Ballachullish, we didnrsquot refuse. Each held their own bike, we sat on the lorry. What magnicent scenery all round.Maryrsquos travelogue notes that while the scenery around Glenfinnan was also impressive, the roads were less so. ldquoBeautul scenery, she wrote. ldquoBut the road becomes dreadful. Gosh stones, holes and no road in places.ldquoA lorry full of sand going past stopped and took all four of us, bikes  all.The kindness of strangers and camaraderie among fellow travellers is a common theme running through her diary. Having been dropped off, the trio went in search of food only to find a hillside house empty.ldquoWe drank water from the burn and ate dry bread. A passing motorist and three women passengers stopped and gave us lemonade.The sisters crossed from Mallaig to the Isle of Skye, taking in a glorious sunset that cast a multitude of colours on the still water of a loch and marvelling at miles of moor with nothing but sheep and heather.Their journey saw them travel from Kyle of Lochalsh south through Dalwhinnie to Dunkeld before swinging east for Coupar Angus, and then turning for home via Perth, Dunblane, Fintry and Bearsden.While it would have taken a physical toll, the sisters made do with basic meals, some provided by locals happy to share their own food with the unlikely adventurers.Other times they simply had to make do: as they headed to Invergarry and having climbed four miles uphill with their bikes, the trio dined on ldquobare bread, cheese and water. But it was good, wrote Mary.Their most pleasing times were spent staying in one of the many youth hostels that had sprung up in the previous five years.Mary, one of a rapidly growing number of Hostelling Scotland members at the time, wrote of encountering fellow travellers, swapping stories and freshening up ndash once bathing in a tub filled by kettles of boiling water, and on another occasion under a cold shower. ldquoGee, there were howls, she wrote.While the epic -day trail might have earned them a rest, the sisters arrived home anxious to get going again.ldquoThe end of a great holiday while we wait eagerly for the time to come again, Mary concluded.Having arrived home, the sisters were soon ready to head off again ndash the next day they packed their haversacks and set off for an -day cycle tour of Northern Ireland.A spokesperson for Hostelling Scotland said: ldquoSince , bike technology and bike apparel has evolved considerably but the roads have got incredibly busy and a great deal more dangerous for cyclists.ldquoHowever, the mentality of exploration and the thirst for adventure has always remained strong.ldquoCycling is an accessible form of sustainable tourism, and Youth Hostels are great, affordable bases for cycling adventures throughout Scotland.

title: nicola-sturgeon-give-ted-talk-part-countdown-cop26-series
story: The First Minister will set out Scotlands ambitions on climatechange on theinternational stage speaking about the role of smaller countries in climate action, aspart of the TEDCountdown to COP series.The Countdown Summit will bring together leaders in Edinburgh from October -, with speakers sharing their blueprint for a net zero future.Its the first-ever in-person TED climate conference, withpoliticians, business leaders, policy makers, scientists, Indigenous leaders, artists, philanthropists, and youth activists gathering in Scotlands capital for four days.Its not the first time Sturgeon has done a TED talk as she previously spoke for the  in July  on the subject, Why governments should prioritize well-being.The talk has accumulated nearly .m views.The following day, on October ,the First Minister will take on another major speechatthe Arctic Circle Assembly in Reykjaviacutek, Iceland.She will talk to Scotlandrsquos links with Arctic nations and how all countries must work together to tackle the climate emergency.Other speakers will include the Prime Minister of Iceland, the Danish Minister for Foreign Affairs and the EU Commissioner for Environment, Oceans and Fisheries.:Sturgeon challenged to rip up Heathrow Airport deal before COPThe First Minister said: "We are now just three weeks away from what will be one of the most important global gatherings of the st century."COP is our best and possibly last chance to achieve what is required to deliver the goals of the Paris Agreement and safeguard our planet.ldquoThe world must move from promises to action, and mobilise the ambition, finance, resources and joint working needed to deliver on the Paris Agreement goals. Scotland will play its full part in meeting those goals.ldquoAhead of COP, Scotland is delivering on our promise to end our contribution to climate change within a generation, putting a just transition and wellbeing at the centre whilst taking the big and dficult decisions that will create a net zero, climate-resilient and fairer future.

title: mammoth skate landed at hatston
story: If you go fishing off Hatston Pier, you may be in for a big surprise!That was certainly the case for Kirkwall welder Garry Mouzon, who landed a lb skate, last night.Garry, who says he has been trying for months now to catch the elusive fish, was delighted to hook the mammoth specimen. He was able to get a predicted weight for the skate with the help of friends Martyn Lennie and Graham Lowrie, by measuring its width and . From wing to wing, the skate measured ,mm. It was ,mm from nose to tail.Having thrown the fish back into the watery depths, the -year-old fishing enthusiast is now determined to beat his own record — with his sights on an even bigger catch.#The one I caught was a male, and the females are usually bigger,# he said.#So I#ll be going back to look for the girlfriend next!#More in next Thursday#s The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orbital turbine reaches global summit
story: Orbital Marine Power has been chosen as one of only  companies invited to take part in this month#s Global Investment Summit , hosted by the Prime Minister and supported by members of the Royal Family.Set to take place on October  in London, the summit aims to showcase the most innovative green technologies and companies already operating in the UK and will highlight the UK’s leading global position and commitment to Net Zero.Working towards delivery of the Prime Minister’s Ten Point Plan for a Green Industrial Revolution, the Summit will bring  of the world’s most prominent decision makers, C-Suite executives, and investors to the UK.The Hatston-based company will be exhibiting its ground-breaking tidal technology, having delivered its MW turbine O to Orkney back in May.Orbital CEO, Andrew Scott, said: “Being selected to exhibit at the Global Investment Summit is a huge honour for Orbital Marine Power and a unique opportunity for us to showcase our bold vision that can help turn the tide on climate change to some of the most influential investors in the world.”The O turbine project has also gained praise from UK investment minister, Gerry Grimestone, ahead of the summit.Mr Grimestone said: #The Global Investment Summit will put UK innovation on the map and demonstrate how we can use investment to nurture technological developments and propel our economy towards a more prosperous, exciting future.#Our showcase businesses show why the UK is a global hub for green technology, and I am proud that Orbital Marine Power will be presenting their innovative tidal turbine technology to some of the world#s most high profile investors at the summit.#Our industries of the future like tidal will not only help ensure a cleaner, greener planet but also create high value jobs in Scotland and across the UK.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney loves local loyalty card competition returns
story: Christmas shopping is set to get a whole lot easier for one lucky person, as The Orcadian’s Loves Local Loyalty Card competition makes a grand .Up for grabs is an amazing £, prize pot — to be spent in any one of the  local shops, businesses and retailers taking part in the competition — as, once again, all eyes firmly fix on supporting the fantastic breadth of businesses we boast in Orkney.Launched last year in response to the impact of the COVID pandemic, the competition helped generate at least £, in revenue — with estimates showing that around £, was spent during the nine-week competition.Included in this week#s The Orcadian is all you need to get started including the all-important card, and be in with a chance to take home the four-figure sum, with the winner due to be announced in the newspaper on December .The concept of the competition is simple.All you need to do is spend £ or more on five separate occasions in the shops and retailers listed in The Orcadian, and you will receive a Loves Local sticker in the process.When you collect five stickers, you can enter the prize draw and be in with a chance of winning the £, total.Completed cards are to be dropped off at The Orcadian Bookshop or The Orcadian   Print Orkney offices at Hatston, and there is no set limit on the number of entries per person. More cards will be availablerequired.All entries have to be in by am on Friday, November .The Orcadian’s editor Leah Seator said: “We are absolutely delighted to be able to bring this brilliant promotion back to shoppers, after the success of last year’s competition.“It was first created in a bid to support businesses, as we all struggled to stay afloat in the thick of the pandemic. Now, as we continue to recover and look ahead, it is imperative that we continue to work together to support and bolster the local economy.“Orkney Loves Local is designed to remind people of the true value of shopping local, and to give something back to our readers, infor their loyalty to Orkney businesses. “We are delighted to see so many retailers taking part this year, and we hope the initiative is every bit as successful as it was in . Good luck to all, and happy shopping!”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: roundabout resurfacing work to begin
story: oicRoundabout resurfacing work to beginOctober ,  at : amWork to resurface Ayre Mills roundabout is to get underway today, Monday, October .The road works on the roundabout is being carried out in two phases.The first phase of the works will involve closing the access on to the roundabout from Pickaquoy Road and Hatston Brae with a signed ersion route via Crowness Crescent, Grainshore Road, Ayre Road and Junction Road.The second phase will then close the Grainshore Road and Ayre Road accesses on to the roundabout with ersions via Crowness Crescent, Hatston Brae, Pickaquoy Road and Junction Road.The council wishes to apologies for delays and inconvenience caused during the resurfacing of the roundabout, and once again thank the public for their understanding as we carry out this important work.Works recently publicised to start on the A through St Marys, Holm on Monday, October , will now not start on that date.Updates will be provided as above when the new start date is available.To find out more about road resurfacing plans for the next two weeks, visit https:www.orkney.gov.uk News postidcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: school pupils urged put pen to paper in dialect writing competition
story: That#s the challenge being set to school bairns across the county, as the Orkney Native Wildle Project and the Orkney International Science Festival team up to launch a brand new writing competition.Taking inspiration from Robert Macfarlane’s project, The Lost Words, the competition will celebrate some commonly used and ‘lost’ Orkney words.You could write a poem about the striking red feet of the black guillemot, known in Orkney as a tystie a story about the misunderstood brute of the sky the great skua, known in these parts as a bonxie. You could create a song celebrating the majestic and powerful king of the sea, the orca or you could focus on the threats faced by our native wildle.Using the Orcadian dialect is a must with extra credit going to those who use lesser known, nearly lost words. If you would rather perform your piece than putting pen to paper that’s no problem at all, you can send in videos — the more creative the better!copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: stagecoach pay offer aims to halt industrial action
story: newsStagecoach pay offer aims to halt industrial actionOctober ,  at : amStagecoach has submitted a fresh pay offer in a bid to prevent industrial action by workers in Orkney and across the Highlands.Confirming its offer, this Thursday morning, Stagecoach Highlands said it hoped to break the deadlock and reach an agreement with trade union Unite.New deals will be put to Unite in talks next week covering employees in Kirkwall, Inverness, Tain, Portree, Thurso, and Aviemore.This follows warnings from Unite that bus transport in these areas could be #brought to a halt# this autumns, as its members ballot on whether to take industrial action short of a strike.In a release from Stagecoach, this morning, Stagecoach Highlands# managing director, David Beaton, said: #Buses are a leline for local people across the Highlands and Islands. We are committed to ensuring our people who keep our communities connected are properly rewarded, particularly after their contribution to the country over the past  months of the pandemic.“We have worked tirelessly to protect the jobs of our people during the pandemic and done everything we reasonably can to hold constructive discussions with Unite to reach a sensible and sustainable pay agreement across our bus depots.“We are leaving no stone unturned in a bid to reach a settlement. That is why we are putting a fresh pay offer to Unite in talks scheduled to take place next week.”According to Stagecoach, bus services are facing a continuing challenging financial environment with passenger levels signicantly down on pre-COVID levels. Passenger fares are signicantly short of what is needed to cover the day-to-day costs of running services without Scottish Government support.Mr Beaton added: “We would urge Unite to end the uncertainty for our people and the customers who rely on bus services.“Strike action is completely unnecessary and would simply damage the lives and livelihoods of hard-working people, including our employees, as well as the region’s businesses.#We would urge Unite to put communities first and talk, not walk.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: isles pupils in national spaceport competition
story: Isles pupils have taken part in a national spaceport competition, designed to promote UK spaceflight to younger audiences.The competition, run in conjunction with Lockheed Martin and the Royal Aeronautical Society, saw pupils given a brief to design a UK Spaceport to launch space vehicles.Pupils had to think about the buildings and facilities needed at a space port and consider the cost and performance of any programme.They also had to adapt their plans to the quality of the land they were building on, and be aware of any archaeological and environmentally sensitive areas.The competition was aimed at P and S pupils, and pupils and staff from eight schools were involved – Anderson and Brae High Schools Baltasound, Sandwick and Whalsay Junior High Schools and Hamnavoe, Happyhansel and Cullivoe Primary Schools.Designing a spaceport undoubtedly involves multidisciplinary themes including engineering, sustainability analysis and budgeting. But pupils had to also develop their presentation skills to explain their design plans to their peers.The Spaceflight Programme, run by the UK Space Agency, has invested over £M to develop three spaceports in Cornwall, Shetland and Sutherland. The UK will soon have the ability to launch small satellites from horizontal and vertical launchers operating from spaceports located around the UK, including the SaxaVord UK Spaceport in Unst.The work done by Shetland pupils will be submitted for judging, with the winning designs announced in the coming weeks.Head Teacher at Whalsay School Garry Spence said: “Our pupils have worked really well together in their groups and they’ve been fully engaged with this competition. They’ve learned a lot about spaceports and we hope some of them have been inspired to consider work in the space industry, which realistically could soon be in Shetland.”..Shetland is on the cusp of a major boost with the UK government ready to approve the creation of an isles spaceport in Unst – aTwo inspection reports have been ed for isles schools, providing mixed results.#Nothing has changed# in the race to bring a spaceport to Unst. title: make the most of stunning lighthouse sculptures while they remain on show
story: Time is running out to visit three spectacular sculptures launched to shine ldquoa light in the dark for people affected by cancer.The lighthouse displays went on display in August at Lerwick Harbourrsquos Victoria Pier Sumburgh Head and Scalloway, as part of Clan Cancer Supportrsquos interactive trail.In all, the Light the North campaign has featured  sculptures across Shetland, Orkney, Aberdeen,Aberdeenshire and Moray.But with the trail set to end next Sunday, folk are being encouraged to make the most of it while it lasts.ldquoLight Stitch, the detailed, eye-catching design selected by the LPA, was created by Leah Pendleton who was inspired by traditional Fair Isle patterns and Shetland flag colours to create a knitted-effect lighthouse.Shetland artist Yolanda Brucersquos lighthouse, titled ldquoThe Way Home, has been on show at Sumburgh Head, inspired by the sea charts, nautical navigation symbols and shipping forecasts she remembers from her youth.The ldquoLittle Lightsrsquo educational project, with  sculptures, has also been supported backed by the LPA in partnership with Lerwickrsquos Bellrsquos Brae Primary School.Currently at Mareel, the schoolrsquos lighthouse will be sent with the others to the Gordon Barracks, Aberdeen, where all the lighthouses will be brought together for a farewell viewing at an all-ticket weekend fundraiser on th-st October.The finale will be an auction of all the large lighthouses at Thainstone Centre, Inverurie, on st November, with opportunities to bid for unique works-of-art from the trail and provide a final boost to the campaign.The pupilsrsquo little lighthouse will be ed to Bellrsquos Brae Primary.Visit www.lightthenorth  for more...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. title: student initiative is hoped to attract young dentists to live and work in shetland after graduating
story: Student dentists arrived in Shetland this week as part of a pilot scheme providing outreach experience in spite of the challenges of the pandemic.Mr Viscocchi hopes it may also inspire young dentists to come and live and work in Shetland.Student dentists have struggled to gather the required experience due to the restrictions of Covid-. Aberdeen students usually attend Stornoway and Elgin for their outreach studies, but it was feared the pandemic may be unable to fulfil their requirements due to the pandemic.The first two students were Ayesha Ahmad and Kelvin Onyinah who treated  patients in four days.Mr Onyinah added: ldquoThe staff have been very supportive and Irsquom really grateful for the opportunity to have experienced dentistry in Shetland.all their support in setting up this scheme and the energy they had towards it.ldquoThey were so enthusiastic with the students when they arrived and itrsquos been great to watch.ldquoIrsquod also like to thank the patients who have been very understanding and provided the students with such encouraging and positive feedback.welcome students from Aberdeen each year.Mr Visocchi hopes young dentists will want toto live and work after graduating to improve dental service provision for the community...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. title: with love from shetland wool donation makes its way to syrian refugee women in beirut
story: A shipment of wool donated by generous Shetlanders has made its way hundreds of miles to help with the empowerment of Syrian refugees.Shetland artist Janice Armstrong, who launched the appeal earlier this year, said yesterday the boxes of wool had been met with a ldquowonderful reaction.The wool was donated to the Sabbara social enterprise in Beirut to support its aimsproviding income and empowerment for vulnerable women through their production of high-end handmade products such as cushions, tablecloths, bedspreads, and accessories.Around kg was donated by kind-hearted Shetland folk earlier this year.Initially, it was stored at C#est la Vie cafeacute in Lerwick, before Northwards transported it south, free of charge, to Cambridge, from where it continued onwards to Beirut in Lebanon.Janice said everything had gone ldquodisconcertingly quiet for several months, with the delays likely posed by the chaotic situation, locally.ldquoSo it was with huge relief and absolute delight that we received photos and videos just two days ago showing the boxes at last safely at the Sabbara headquarters and the wonderful reaction of the women to them, she said.ldquoI have not stopped smiling myself.ldquoI cannot thank enough all the people who have helped, first and foremost to those who rummaged in their cupboards for bags of wool, Valerie and Didier at C#est la Vie for receiving, storing and helping to pack the wool and to Northwards Transport for so kindly delivering it gratis to Cambridge.ldquoA team effort and a very happy result. title: norrie t macdonald crofts have become the the bitcoin of the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineYes, it’s more of a hobby than a full-time commitment, but it’s ‘in the blood’.. But were it not for Murdo Dan’s job as a joiner and Chrissie Mary doing a few shts as a carer, their economic ‘situation’ would be very dficult indeed.To supplement their income, they have decided to use their meagre savings, borrow a not insignicant sum from their local bank, and apply to stick a couple of pods on the croft.Meanwhile, Nigel and Pippa saw a croft for sale in the Sunday Times Property Section for what they thought was a snip at £k and decided to use part of a trust fund to purchase it as a commercial investment.They thought that they could also capitalise on the local tourist ‘boom’ and have applied to turn the derelict croft house into a vegan cafe and craft shop and also to stick several pods on their newly acquired croft to offer a ‘holistic getaway’ for their jet-set pals.Do you, and I certainly don’t mean to pre-judge anyone who reads this paperthink that their ‘cases’ should be treated any dferently by the local planning authorities If the answer is “yes”, then think again.Too dficult a scenario to judge Try this one.Should an application to build a couple of pods on a croft, which is basically  per cent bog, in the middle of Ranish and has no view of anywhere except adjacent croft bog, be given any additional merit over a similar application in beautul Scaristavore or Ardroil where ‘breathtaking scenery’ will be the selling tagline Wrong again.As a member of the local planning board here in the Western Isles, I’m more than well aware of what my responsibilities are and it’s certainly not to pre-judge any applications based on my own preconceptions, or prejudicesof what should or shouldn’t be allowed.I’ve to stick to the guidelines and the training I’ve been given, understand what’s expected of meand to base my decision without emotion or bias. across the front pages of this paper and others, on social media and the television news, can influence any of my our decisions.The capitalist playground which crofting tenure has now become, and the seismic change in the scale of speculation on ‘marketable’ properties available, is in danger of knocking the fragile socio-economic balance of the west of Scotland even further off its already very shoogly axis.Crofts have now become the equivalent of crypto-currency the ‘Bitcoins’ which can provide financial security for those fortunate enough to be sitting on ‘gold’.What’s being done to stabilise and bring a dose of reality to a market which threatens to get completely out of control How can single iniduals be able to own several crofts with not an intention to ‘work’ or develop any single one of them I believe that a crofting historian once said that this form of land tenure has become ‘the single biggest impediment to sustainable development in Western Scotland and the Highlands and Islands’.That wasn’t yesterday.‘Things’ are already well out of control.But who should intervene I’m not the only one who keeps asking the question.Apparently ‘we’ should legislate to address.We need, it has been suggested, to become Jersey or Guernsey.That people shouldn’t be allowed to buy homes here unless they intend to be used as a primary residence .Second homes taxation needs to increase signicantly and the additional income be used to support tourism infrastructure.From the Butt to Bodmin there have been ious proposals as to how to legislate to prevent the worst effects of tourism from destroying fragile local economies.Have any worked, andso, could they be implemented here to make any dference Let me be very clear.Tourism is hugely important to our rural economy.More so since Brexit and Covid.But I’ll say this again, at the risk of boring you all: it needs to be carefully nurtured and sustainably developed.We cannot survivewe turn our villages into ‘ghost-towns’#yes, I know…..for the winter months.We need a balance, we need the ‘tools’ with which to legislate properly and we need those charged with ‘oversight’ to take better ownership.We need, and I’ve yet to see any evidence of this, these same people to begin to take this seriously.For our future generations.They are the ones who will be impacted mostwe don’t sit up and pay attention.Now.

title: remember your roots skye plan is urged to recognise
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThose were the comments of Roddy Murray, former Western Isles councillor and now the grazings clerk for Tarskavaig in Sleat, who this week voiced his concern that there was no mention of crofting at all in the ‘Skye and Raasay Future’ plan published in August with the full backing of all four local councillors.He told the Free Press: “There are  projects listed in the plan but not a single mention of crofting. Crofting is the basis for so many of the settlements on Skye outwith Portree, Broadford and Kyleakin and this should have been acknowledged.“There is quite a signicant impact from crofting on the economic and social well-being of Skye and Raasay. You only have to look at the , high quality calves sold for high prices last week in Portree to see that.”In terms of infrastructure improvements to support crofting, Mr Murray said the auction mart in Portree must be redeveloped to improve parking and animal welfare, and an abattoir facility must be provided so that livestock does not have to be driven to Dingwall.He added: “We are being told by the Scottish Crofting Federation that there is a huge demand for new crofts.#To meet that demand we either have to encourage landowners to make this happen or there has to be acquisition of an estate.“If we want to keep our young people in our communities we need to address the availability of crofts.”The Scottish Government are guilty of an “abject failure” when it comes to creating new crofts on publicly-owned land, Mr Murray added.Stung by the criticism, the council said they hoped to “discuss the plan further with organisations like the Crofting Commission” and would be keen to hear from any other interested parties.A spokeswoman said: “Skye and Raasay Future has been prepared with and by wider representatives of the community across the area.#It reflects people’s vision and priorities for the future, following feedback gathered through workshops and online consultations held throughout the year.“In workshop discussions, the important role that crofting plays in the identity and culture of Skye and Raasay communities has been clearly referenced..#Skye councillor John Finlayson said all stakeholders should be involved in “shaping, evaluating and changing” the plan’s priorities and he acknowledged the importance of crofting “in all its guises” across Skye and Raasay.He added: “Crofting is still a central part of le on Skye and while it is part of our history and culture it will also I hope continue to be a key part of our future and it is an important element of SARF.#As those who took part in the engagement to create the initial plan agreed, it is important that representatives from the crofting community are fully engaged in the continued development and implementation of the plan and I am confident this will happen.”

title: portglenone firm launch innovative new coffin pod
story: A Portglenone hearse building firm has credited the support received from Mid and East Antrim Borough Council in helping secure funding to launch an innovative ‘Coffin Pod’ which will help protect grieving families and funeral directors as the COVID- pandemic continues.Family-owned Quinn Hearse  Limousines have specialised in the design and manufacture of hearses and limousines for over a quarter of a century, and currently employ  staff.The company’s revolutionary new product has been launched following extensive market research after Quinn’s were awarded the Innovate NI Gold Standard accreditation.The Coffin Pod is a sealed glass pod which will allow funeral directors to transport coffins safely, and allow families to have open coffin wakes while observing social distancing measures.The development of the new product has been made possible with the support of a network of stakeholders, including the council’s Economic Development team, Innovate UK and Invest NI.Patrick Quinn, Company Director, said: “Innovation and new product development have been core to the business’s continued success. We had the idea to develop the Coffin Pod, after seeing the impact that Covid- was having on families being unable to properly mourn for their loved ones and to protect funeral directors in transport to their final resting place. Mid and East Antrim Borough Council have supported us through the process of applying for the Innovate UK Challenge Fund to address the current and future impacts of Covid-. With their support, we successfully secured the funding to develop our Coffin Pod.“We are delighted to have now launched this into the market, and to have been awarded the Innovate NI Gold standard for this product. We continue to develop our core product ranges of hearses and limousines and have several new vehicles under development.”Speaking about the ongoing support received by the council, Patrick added:“Through our interaction with Council’s Business Client Manager, Barbara Orr we have received support through the Business Escalator and Business Escalator Plus Programmes to develop our export markets and growth development. The support through the programmes and assistance from Barbara has been truly worthwhile and I would recommend that businesses in our borough take advantage of the help available.“As we continue to move forward, we aim to make use of the assistance in the many dferent areas of running our business, to grow and create more jobs for the people of Ballymena.”Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, said: “Quinn Hearse  Limousine is just one of many companies across Mid and East Antrim to have benefitted from support via Council’s Amply programmes, since the launch of our economic development strategy in .“As well as supporting our SMEs to navigate through the current challenges posed by COVID-, we are preparing for the new economic landscape as we navigate post lockdown, and have provided expert guidance to support Quinn Hearse  Limousine with its longer-term business development strategy.”Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s Business Escalator and Escalator Plus Programmes are part funded by Invest Northern Ireland and the European Regional Development Fund under the Investment for Growth  Jobs Northern IrelandProgramme.To find out more make an enquiry today via midandeastantrim.gov.uk EscalatorPlus

title: minister urged to support young people who missed out on education due to covid with new catch up policy
story: Michelle McIlveen. Credit: Brian Morrison FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle McIlveen. Credit: Brian MorrisonMark BainTwitterEmailOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDUP minister Michelle McIlveen will be asked to bring forward an Education Catch-Up policy to help pupils who missed out on school during lockdown tomorrow at Stormont.A motion will be brought to MLAs by Colin McGrath, with the SDLP MLA keen for politicians to recognise the impact young people have made during the Covid- pandemic.It will ask the Department of Education to step up commitments made to support young people, through proper funding for schemes that have played a critical role in supporting communities, and to ensure all means to negate the effect of missed education are taken.Speaking ahead of his motion, the South Down MLA praised the youth service for its response to the Covid- pandemic.Mr McGrath said youth workers and organisations had stepped up to the mark and supported the mental health and developmental needs of young people during a very dficult time.He said they now deserved recognition and urged Education Minister Michelle McIlveen to bring forward an Education Catch-Up Strategy.“There is an army of volunteers and youth workers who did all they could during the Covid- pandemic to adapt and address the needs of our young people,” said Mr McGrath, who chairs Stormont’s Executive Office Committee. “They took to the streets to meet outdoors, they met young people via Zoom, they engaged through every technological means they could so that the mental health, socialisation and engagement of young people was to the highest standard.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseColin McGrath. they are eager to explain the reasons why a party characterised as one of men in grey suits not so long ago is no longer a cold house for them.Read MoreStormont needs a ‘rethink’ claims UUP’s Beattie, as leader says he’s ‘playing to win’ next electionSuzanne Breen:OpinionStatesmanlike leader Doug Beattie doesn’t miss a step with a speech on the moveSouth Down candidate Jill Macauley addressed the crowd at the UUP conference on Saturday to express her dismay at “the current lack of females in elected politics”.“Women are not a minority we are half of the world’s population, and female representation is necessary to ensure that democracy s most effectively,” she said.Describing herself as “mum, we, daughter, dairy farmer, bad tractor driver, business owner and political fanatic who probably talks too much” as well as a “proud country girl” Jill is a case study of the relatable politician which the UUP is striving to portray.Macauley has been a party member from her teens and played an active role within South Down for the last  years, but is relatively new to local government after being co-opted onto Newry, Mourne and Down District Council in .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up She said it’s only now she is taking the leap of faith into Assembly candidacy because “the time is right”.“There is an air of optimism that I haven’t experienced before within the party,” she told Belfast , explaining that the new party leader’s “refreshing charismatic and inclusive nature makes people want to join him”.Adding that her personal circumstances of raising a young family didn’t fit well with an Assembly role before, she feels now is the time to “see real change” especially for women in unionism.“There’s a long history of women in unionism and I feel the UUP represents that well,” she said, “but we need to revive this.”“The Ulster Women’s Council was formed back in  and in its first year they had , members.“This number has obviously dropped dramatically over the course of its -year history, perhaps because the isiveness of politics in Northern Ireland has made women shy away, but now is the time to make this change, and there is a real appetite for it,” she added.During lockdown, the Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough councillor created an online forum appealing for women to get involved in a “pro-Union dialogue”.Entitled ‘We Need You Girl’, Jill, along with party colleagues and fellow councillors Julie Flaherty and Louise McKinstry, put out an invite to those interested in starting the conversation around what women in Northern Ireland want to see from unionism.“We engaged with women from Foyle, North Antrim, Fermanagh, as well as Newry and Armagh, we reached out to most constituencies across Northern Ireland and I feel we really made a dference to changing perceptions around the party,” she said.“It was so encouraging to see each woman engage each for a dferent reason, each one perhaps not that confident in their own conviction, but the relationship we have developed over past few months has helped these women to decide that the UUP is the party for them.”Jill, however, is no stranger to standing up for her party by herself and was, at one point, the sole female unionist councillor on Newry, Mourne and Down District Council.“Despite being the only unionist woman at this time, I still felt part of a team, because the UUP reassured that I was accepted by them,” she said.Although she felt frustrated at the lack of women choosing the UUP to represent them, Macauley made it very clear that recruiting pro-Union females was “not just a box-ticking exercise”.“We definitely felt that young women in particular were not engaging in politics because maybe it wasn’t cool,” she said.“But there is so much to achieve from starting a conversation with them around what they can do to improve unionism for all. One thing I don’t agree with is to put a woman in a position just to tick a box, but to put a woman in a position in her own right.“I feel you need to support women and ask them to step forward, and allow them to make their own decision, and that’s what we’ve done.“This year especially has definitely seen steep rise in interest of women joining the ranks of the party we have teachers, accountants, farmers, stay-at-home-mums and everyone in between of all ages which really is a breath of fresh air for the party.“We want to show the world the extraordinary, talented women we already have in politics, and celebrate those who have gone before us, to inspire the next generation of girls to step up and join us as a Union of People.”Laura Turnerhas only joined the party in the past year and is already progressing as a Lagan Valley candidate in the upcoming Assembly election.“I first took part in a cross-community initiative led by the Department of Foreign Affairs about six years ago and that was really what highlighted to me the lack of confident women in unionism, and I aspired to become one of those,” she said.“So over the past few years I have been active in promoting women’s voices at grassroots level, and I feel this new  will just help further cement that drive to be able to represent women in unionism.“If you take policy scrutiny, it would be flawed on principleit didn’t have a women’s perspective.”Laura said that Saturday was her very first time attending a UUP conference, and she decided to enter the world of politics for the very first time only earlier this year ago because the qualities of the party was something she could “fully align with”.“Since the beginning I have just felt valued, accepted and supported by the UUP,” she said.“I strongly believe more female representation is needed and in the party there is a real, authentic drive to encourage more women into politics.”Turner added that the reason for the increased emphasis on female politicians is “not just about gender equality, we all got here on our own merit, so it’s about representing the needs of the people with a women’s perspective”.“With Doug at the helm, we believe that we can now be heard and provide a voice for future generations, while also being proactive in delivering the solutions,” she said.Commenting on the recently released UUP election broadcast which features a same-sex couple, Laura simply stated “love is love”.“I’m all for progressive politics and forward-thinking ideals,” she said.“The video perfectly encapsulated what the union of people is all about, I think there is more to be said about how we treat each other, there needs to be mutual respect there.“The Ulster Unionist Party are definitely youth advocates, aiming towards story: NI manager hits out at stars after dficult season as he eyes move to IsraelExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseTough time: Neil Lennon managing Celtic during his last season at the club. Credit: Andrew Milligan FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTough time: Neil Lennon managing Celtic during his last season at the club. Credit: Andrew MilliganRalph HewittTwitterEmailOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFormer Celtic manager Neil Lennon has claimed some of his players pulled out of fixtures when fit as Rangers halted the club’s -in-a-row quest last season.The Lurgan man resigned as manager of the Parkhead club in February after taking charge of Celtic for the second time in  when Brendan Rodgers left for Leicester City.He led the Old Firm outfit to two League titles, two Scottish Cups and a League Cup in that period.The former Celtic captain faced angry protests from fans who were furious the club had fallen so far behind Steven Gerrard’s Rangers in the title race — effectively ending their bid to win the league for an unprecedented th consecutive season.Lennonsaid some of his former players had “just got to the end of the road” after winning nine league titles in a row and four trebles.“You could see it pre-season, the body language, they weren’t with us,” he told The Scottish Sun. “You could smell it.Some players could have played but didn’t, Lennon added, although he stopped short of saying they were feigning injury. He added: “This eats into the dressing room. You’ve got great pros like Scott Brown and Callum McGregor, unbelievably successful, being .”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Lennon said Celtic had been in fine form before lockdown in March  but the players “found it dficult to adjust” after ing three months later.He highlighted European giants Juventus, PSG, Real Madrid, Barcelona and Liverpool as being in the same “unprecedented” situation as Celtic, as they too failed to win their leagues — despite being heavy favourites.The Celtic fan added he did not want to leave Parkhead but he wanted to do what was best for the club, “especially with what Celtic means to me”.“People think it’s easy coming up here but you have to win every week — a draw isn’t good enough,” he said.Lennon, who is keen toto management, also admitted he is open to going overseas to find a new club, with Israel being one potential option.Speaking on football management agency Scoutpush’s social media, which is operated by agent Dudu Dahan, Lennon said he has a good knowledge of the Middle Eastern game through some of the players he worked with at Celtic.“For starters, Israel is a beautul country,” he said. “I have a great affiliation with Israel, with the football, because of the players I have worked with and people I have met like Dudu, friends and colleagues over the years.“I have a good relationship with Dudu, who is a big agent in Israel, and he brought me lots of players.“I have always kept an eye on the bigger clubs, like Maccabi, like Be’er Sheva, even Ashdod because we took Efe Ambrose from there originally.“So definitely, it would be something that I am interested in. I have always wanted to work abroad.”The former Bolton Wanderers manager also dismissed suggestions he is too fiery and said “all the best managers have an edge”.“People have a misconception of me Photo by Peter Morrison FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFun: Dave Finlay with daughter Wendy and Nick Campbell. Photo by Peter MorrisonAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFor the first time in almost three decades, figures from the golden age of Northern Irish wrestling met up for a reunion in Belfast at the weekend, providing a glimpse into a world where characters with names like the Lone Wolf and Ricky Valentine reigned supreme.Long retired wrestlers gathered at the Lansdowne Hotel to reminisce and share stories about the industry back in the s and s. The event was the work of Nick Campbell, who promotes wrestling shows here and has written a book on the history of the sport on these shores, entitled Falls, Brawls and Town Halls: The History of Professional Wrestling in Northern Ireland.Theroom in the hotel was like travelling back in time, decked out with old promotional wrestling posters from shows here and clippings telling stories from the ring.Speaking to the Belfast , Nick spoke about how the event and his book came to be.I actually put on local wrestling shows here and was very interested in what came before us. I had heard of course of Fit Finlay, the most famous wrestler from Northern Ireland, who fought in the s and s, so I looked at people who wrestled around the same time, he said.I got in touch with an old wrestler from Belfast called Eddie Hamill and some of the stories he told me were just incredible. Over time I met other wrestlers and the family of Fit Finlay, his father Dave and sister Wendy, and I just went from there. Wrestling back then and wrestling now are just dferent worlds. Speaking to wrestlers like Ricky Valentine, the Lone Wolf, and Noel Arnott — who is NI#s oldest living former pro wrestler at  — I knew I had to write the book.The book is half oral history and half drawn from research, old newspaper articles, posters and things. It took me the best part of two years and I#m really happy with the results.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFit Finlay, who is Dave’s son FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFit Finlay, who is Dave’s sonDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up So what is the dference between pro wrestling #back in the day#, compared to now  Nick pointed out that there were only a few TV channels in the s and s, so live entertainment was a huge draw.There were events in places like Enniskillen where there were , people in attendance, featuring legendary wrestlers like Giant Haystacks. Events in Portrush drew , to , fans and there were even bigger shows in the Ulster Hall and the King#s Hall, Nick said.Today the reality is everyone is fighting for the attention andyou want to make a living out of wrestling, you have to get out of Ireland really. The scene here now is grand, but it#s so dferent than what it was. It#s great to have everyone here, because the last time these people had a reunion was in , when I was two years old.The Belfastalso spoke to Wendy Finlay, who, in addition to being the sister of wrestling royalty, was one of the first ever female referees in the industry. Her father Dave was also a wrestler and promoter.She praised the event and Nick’s working bringing everyone together.When my dad took up the wrestling I always wanted to be with him, but he kept saying #it#s for men#, which I didn#t agree with. But I kept at him and he eventually let me join him. So my brother and I helped to build rings and were travelling to shows all the time. That led to coaching and then refereeing.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDave in  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDave in I was always there supporting Fit and my dad. I have such fond memories of that time, lots of stories — some you wouldn#t tell! Wrestling now is so dferent than it was back then, it#s night and day really. My dad finds it hard to get his head around, but you have to move with the times.This event is fantastic, just seeing everyone again, especially for my dad too. What Nick has done is just amazing.Falls, Brawls and Town Halls: The History of Professional Wrestling in Northern Ireland is available to buy now from Amazon and bookstores. .app-box.app-box Credit: Alan Currie Getty ImagesGillian HallidayTwitterEmailOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailNearly two decades on from Lisburn achieving city status, UUP Alderman Jim Dillon has recalled how, in the lead-up to the decision being announced and celebrated with the popping of champagne corks, an official visit was made to the area by then Labour Secretary of State Dr John Reid.At that point, Mr Dillon was mayor, and had been forewarned by a civil servant that Dr Reid, now Baron Reid of Cardowan, had a two-hour window and “not a minute more”.This was two months before the Secretary of State’s visit, and as Mr Dillon noted, it was important Mr Reid left with a good impression, saying: “The Secretary of State plays a big part in it. The day he came and the two hours were up, the secretary walked over to him and said, ‘We need to go now’. He said: ‘Have you another packet of fags  I’ll be here at least another hour yet’.“I came back to my secretary an hour and a quarter later and threw my hands up in the air, [saying], ‘We’re going to get this, we’re going to get this’.”When the secretary asked why he was so sure, he replied, “I just got the vibes today”.The decision was announced by then Lord Chancellor Lord Irvine in March  as part of the Queen’s Golden Jubilee celebrations, giving Lisburn a lord mayor title as well. Other places across the UK received the title.For Northern Ireland, it was a tale of two cities as Newry was also conferred with city status, with Carrickfergus and Ballymena in Co Antrim, Coleraine in Co Londonderry, and Craigavon in Co Armagh missing out.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up This year, the award is for the monarch’s Platinum milestone next year, and Ballymena is in the running for a third time, as well as Bangor.Those hoping to secure the title for their respective towns will, like Mr Dillon, be hoping for positive vibes this time round.Following the announcement  years ago, it was argued, somewhat cynically, that adding the word ‘city’ after Lisburn and Newry was simply an act of political expediency, with Lisburn pleasing unionists and Newry pleasing nationalists.Regardless, Mr Dillon insisted it was a good decision and extolled the benefits it has brought the area in the years since.“Some people will tell you that it has done a whole lot for Lisburn, and others will tell you that it’s done nothing. It’s as simple as that, but people who think it hasn’t [done anything] are not thinking people,” he said. “Cities have to start somewhere. [Modern] London started hundreds of years ago as a small town. It’s a multi-national city now. Lisburn is growing, and the problems we have are planning issues over the last while. We want to expand in dferent directions. Planning takes light years,it gets through at all.“I still think that getting city status was a good boost for Lisburn. It has allowed us to grow, despite all the dficulties. “People want to come and invest in us, simply because we are a city.”Has the award put paid to the perception some people have that Lisburn is merely a satellite of Belfast that will one day be subsumed by the capital The UUP alderman was adamant that would never happen.“In  years’ time, people will see what it has done for Lisburn. Lisburn is not a suburb of Belfast. Lisburn would never join up with Belfast. They are two very dferent places,” he stressed.“People can speculate, but it’s not going to happen. Lisburn is a very thriving place.”Former Newry and Armagh MLA Danny Kennedy was a councillor when he proposed the idea of Newry applying for city status.It was reported at the time that Sinn Fein opposed the move to become a city because of the award’s links with the Queen’s Golden Jubilee.Mr Kennedy remembers a more pragmatic response. “[While] it’s fair to say [the reaction] wasn’t exactly enthusiastic at the time, they had indicated that they wouldn’t object. It was initially a lukewarm reception from the SDLP but it became warmer,” he said, stressing that the combined unionist and SDLP support helped get the project off the ground.“What did help was the reaction and influence of the chamber of commerce. They [councillors] then quickly saw the benefits to the area.“People who were key influences in education and commerce, they in turn reached out to the wider community. “The application then took off and, crucially, avoided the political pitfall you would have thought would come with that.”In the wake of the announcement of city status, Sinn Fein’s Davy Hyland, at that point the council’s chairman, welcomed the decision, telling the BBC: “Royalism wouldn’t be a very strong aspect of le here. The main thing is the recognition that it is now a city.”The late Seamus Mallon, at that time the local SDLP MP, also praised the decision, saying it was a “great day” for the area that pointed towards a “bright future for the city of Newry”.“This is a great day for Newry and represents a strong recognition of the work which has taken place in the city in recent times,” Mr Mallon added.Jaded thinking, however, was a harder stumbling block to overcome, said Mr Kennedy.“Some people were cynical about that, saying that Newry was a town and would always be a town,” he explained.“People were cynical again when both Lisburn and Newry were awarded it, saying it was a political trade-off. People, to this day, still say that. I’ve no evidence for that.“There was genuine goodwill and they were able to assemble a group of businesspeople and sportspeople like [former Northern Ireland footballer] Pat Jennings to come on board. Figures who were recognised as leading in their fields.“It became the creature of the chamber, rather than the council. And that made it easier in some ways because it took the politics out of it.“If I got up every week and asked, ‘Any word from the Queen yet ’, that wasn’t going to work.”While he acknowledged that some people still do not see Newry as a city, he said the status had brought many benefits.“I think it’s worthwhile. You could stand on ceremony and say, ‘Now, hang on. They haven’t got two cathedrals, they haven’t got the population’,” he added.“It’s not on the level of New York and it’s not on the level of those great English cities like Liverpool and Manchester, but there is economic and cultural benefit to it.”A framed copy of the Queen’s certicate conferring the status hangs in Mr Kennedy’s home.“I’m proud of it. It’s not an exclusive achievement of myself, but I was happy to be involved,” he said.“Success has many fathers. I did propose it at council level, but I would concede that most of the spadework was done by the Newry chamber and others.”City status may be a thorny issue that falls along orange and green lines, but it can also reignite long-standing rivalries between towns. Ards and North Down Borough Council recently gave Bangor the green light to pursue city status, but it prompted consternation from councillors who represent other areas, including Newtownards.Alistair Cathcart, a DUP councillor for Bangor Central who proposed that the council support the application, insisted it was a “no-brainer”. “Why go for this now  Because the opportunity is now,” he said.“We simply don’t know when the next opportunity will arise. It’s been  years since the last opportunity. It could be another  or  years into the future for the next one.”Other representatives felt otherwise. Joe Boyle, an SDLP, councillor for the Ards Peninsula branded it “embarrassing,” while Angus Carson, a UUP councillor, denounced it as an April Fool’s joke, insisting Bangor was “going down the tubes”.DUP Alderman Stephen McIlveen, who represents Newtownards, insisted his issue with it went beyond the old rivalry between the two towns, saying it was more to do with what a city is in principle.“The process they have is that any town can apply for city status,” he said. “A lot of people will look at certain towns and think, ‘This does not fit my idea of what a city should be’.“The idea that you can have this process devalues what a city like Belfast or Londonderry might be. “A city should be an economic driver. The idea that somewhere like Ballymena, Bangor or the idea of Lisburn [as a city], a lot of people still cannot accept that because it doesn’t meet the perception of what a city is. Does that devalue what a city is ”Mr McIlveen stressed he would not support a similar proposal for his town. “I feel exactly the same way about Newtownards. I’m guessing thatyou spoke to a lot of people in Newtownards, they would feel the same way,” he explained.“The concern among the chamber in Newtownards is that Bangor,did get city status, it may adversely affect them. “While I’m a councillor for the whole borough, I am a representative for the whole Newtownards town and I have to advocate for them. “If they [Bangor] get it, great. It’s a tremendous honour to attain, but I’m not too sure that many people still consider [Bangor] worthy of being a city.”Children’s Commissioner Koulla Yiasouma agreed.  “I have lived in Bangor for over  years, I have raised my family in Bangor, I love living in Bangor, but I am from London, and Bangor is not a city,” she said.The idea of what defines a city is a concept that fascinates architect Mark Hackett, who operates a practice in Belfast and has written articles for Architectural Review magazine.He believes cities are made by citizens, rather than being made in top-down processes.“Just calling something a city doesn’t make it a city. It’s more emotional than that,” he said. “I’m talking about it more from an urban theory point of view. If you want to have a cohesive city, it needs to have a lot of things in it that people have a lot of pride in. “The ability for people to gather and express civic pride, or civic displeasure or dissent, is a very important thing. If you can’t do that, then it’s not a city or, indeed, a town.”What matters is not whether a place is a town or a city, he argued, but whether it is a “good town, a good city”, regardless of status: “It’s not about the aspiration of getting the title of city conferred from someone . It’s not important how other people decide what your status is. It’s how the residents are. Are they truly invested in their town or their city ”Alderman Audrey Wales MBE, who proposed Ballymena’s application at Mid and East Antrim council, believes the town meets the criteria and more.“Ballymena is a wonderful place. Our citizens are forward-thinking and hard-working, and it really does deserve to be a city,” she said.Itwins, it will be a case of third time lucky. As well as missing out in , Ballymena made an attempt in , when one UK town was to be granted city status to mark the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee.Although Ballymena was nominated on that occasion, it was later withdrawn.“Everyone is looking forward to it just as much as last time,” said Ms Wales.She also stressed there was no rivalry with nearby towns, with the application “fully supported by Larne and Carrickfergus”.As part of the process, applicants must demonstrate “distinct identity”, civic pride, heritage, history, tradition and association with royalty.Carrickfergus could have good reason to apply for city status, given its royal links. Along with its castle, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Baron and Lady Carrickfergus titles were conferred on Prince William and his we Catherine by Her Majesty on their marriage in .While it was not nominated, Ms Wales believes the general feeling is thatBallymena were to be successful, it would have a positive effect on the wider area overall.It would also be somewhat poetic, given the town already welcomes visitors with a sign reading “Ballymena: the City of the Seven Towers” — a proclamation that reflects the spires that once defined its skyline.Ms Wales said: “We’re known as that, so It’s what you now do with that money that’s important because it can be easy to do nothing, and within a few months, the raise gets consumed by increased spending, and this is typically known as lestyle creep i.e. as your income increases, so do your outgoings, by the same amount.     Which is a shame because when you get a raise,put to good use, it should really put you ahead financially and allow you to achieve things, you were unable to on a lower salary.If you don’t take advantage and you’re not intentional with what you’re going to do with it, you end up in exactly the same position as before, and you’re just working harder without living better and that’s not what you want.So, how do you avoid this from happening to you Ideally, you want to give some thought into how you can benefit from your new higher earnings, and I will re-visit this in more detail, in a second follow article next week, because there’s a lot to cover.         However, I do know there are those who are just looking for a number, and don’t want to carry out that deep e into what impact a specic number would have on particular areas of their finances.So, with them and everyone  in mind, I’m going to share with you three very good rules of thumb that I like and think are useful.They were first developed by the financial services giant, Morningstar, and this is what they are suggesting you should do with a raise:. Spend twice your years to retirementIf you have  years to retirement, you can spend % of your raise and save the rest.. Save your age, as a % of the raiseIf you are  years’ old, save % of your raise.. Save at least % of your raiseRegardless of your age or years to your target date for retirement is, just save % of your raise.When Morningstar ran dferent scenarios, they discovered the spend twice your years to retirement created the biggest impact across all age groups because it usually involves saving the most money.The rules I’ve referred to focus on how much of the raise can be spent rather than how much can be saved, and that’s very deliberate i.e. you don’t want people to feel they have to save every extra cent they now earn and can’t enjoy some of the raise they received.Or do they have to save everything I’ll circle back to that in next weeks’ article.In the meantime, I want to make reference to the impact continuing to save a % of your income into your pension after a pay rise is, because its’ important.Pay Raise  PensionsSome people who receive a pay increase but make no % change to their pension contribution, think they are making progress, because they are saving a higher amount, right Wrong.If you continue to save for example % of your income, of course you’re increasing your saving because it’s % of a higher amount, butyou spend the other % and continue to do so, you are increasing your standard of living by % of every rise you receive.The danger with doing this, is that as your standard of living rises, the funding needed for retirement grows at a faster pace than the amount you are saving. Which results in the gap between what you need and what you save, becoming bigger every year.Let me explain.Let’s say your income was €, and it increased to €,.If you were saving % of your salary and continue to do so after your raise, you are increasing your annual contributions by €,, and you’re now saving €, per year.Whilst you might be saving more in absolute terms i.e. % of €, is obviously more than % of €,, you need to save more relative to how much your new salary is,you want to keep up with your new, higher costing lestyle.In this instance,you save % of your raise i.e. €, and add it to what you were previously saving i.e. €,, your new annual saving rate is €,.That % saving from your raise increases your contributions to, % of your new salary and that’s why you’re giving yourself an opportunity to fast forward retirement.What all that means is that the increased retirement savings, combined with the decreased need for retirement funds, means someone aged  who saves % of their raise can retire at , which is  years earlier than someone of the same age who only saved % of their raise.Regardless of your age, continuing to save only a certain % of your salary and spending the rest, including raises, is really poor advice because it can lead to delayed retirement and underfunded accounts, and that’s’ even when your savings rate is higher.Long story short, getting a raise can actually exacerbate the problem of having a fund which is lower than you need when you decide to retire full stop. Instinctively you might think it will help because you’re saving more money.But don’t forget you’re spending more as well and how are you going to replace that You’re certainly not going to do ityou continue to save the same % your currently saving.And let me repeat, even though you’re saving more because its % of a higher amount, when you run the math, it will tell you a dferent story.Okay, next week, I’ll look at people who are carrying high debt and or low savings and I’ll give you my opinion on how much of any raise they receive, they should spend.And in the same article, I’ll also tell you about someone who asked me recently what impact the raise she received would have on her finances. She wanted specic numbers and outputs on a number of dferent areas, and I’ll share with you what we discovered, and what she decided to do.Liam Croke is MD of Harmonics Financial Ltd, based in Plassey.
